title: sky mobile three huawei 5g phone security china
story: IM Subscribe NowIM Subscribe NowCreated with Sketch.IM  Subscribe NowIM  Subscribe NowSubscribe NowSubscribe NowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Try Independent Minds free for 1 monthSee the optionsO2, EE and others have left the Chine company's handsets out of their own 5G offeringsClick to followThe IndependentSky Mobile and Three have become the first mobile operators to promise Huawei’s smartphones on the UK’s new 5G mobile networks, despite security fears about the Chinese technology company.Huawei’s Mate 20 X 5G device is one of a limited number of phones capable of utilising 5G, the fifth generation of mobile networking technology that allows significantly faster connections than its predecessors.The US has said Huawei’s equipment could be used by China to spy on users, an allegation the Chinese company denies.Sky Mobile said it will offer Mate 20 X 5G and Samsung's Galaxy S10 5G when it launches its 5G network in November.Three began offering the Mate 20 on Friday ahead of the roll-out of its 5G offering later this year. Its customers will pay the same for 5G as they currently pay for 4G, the company announced on Friday.Created with Sketch.Europe replicated in Huawei City, China Show all 8Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.18 Karl Theodor Bridge in Heidelberg, Germany28 Replica Karl Theodor Bridge in Huawei City, China48 Replica Heidelberg in Huawei City, China68 Replica Cesky Krumlov in Huawei City, China88 Replica Heidelberg in Huawei City, China18 Karl Theodor Bridge in Heidelberg, Germany28 Replica Karl Theodor Bridge in Huawei City, China48 Replica Heidelberg in Huawei City, China68 Replica Cesky Krumlov in Huawei City, China88 Replica Heidelberg in Huawei City, ChinaOther networks, including EE, Vodafone and O2, have left Huawei’s handset out of their 5G launches.America and a number of other nations have banned Huawei equipment from being used in their 5G networks.On Monday, the UK government delayed the final decision on whether to ban the firm from the country’s 5G networks.Currently, Huawei’s equipment is allowed to be used for “non-core” parts of the UK’s 5G infrastructure and there is nothing to prevent mobile networks from offering the company’s smartphones.“Core” parts of the network include those that check device IDs are checked and decide how to route voice calls and data.Last month Huawei's UK boss, Anson Zhang, said the company had not changed anything about its devices in response to US sanctions and scrutiny in the UK.His comments came weeks after former UK spy chief Sir Richard Dearlove warned that Huawei’s involvement in the 5G network represents a “potential security risk to the UK”.The former MI6 director described reports that the government is ready to permit Huawei to bid for “non-core” elements of the project as “deeply worrying”.Only the best news in your inboxOnly the best news in your inboxEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. title: sports direct annual results delay mike ashley house fraser
story: IM Subscribe NowIM Subscribe NowCreated with Sketch.IM  Subscribe NowIM  Subscribe NowSubscribe NowSubscribe NowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Try Independent Minds free for 1 monthSee the optionsThe report, due to update investors on the performance of House of Fraser, was originally scheduled for 18 JulyClick to followThe IndependentSports Direct has postponed the publication of its latest annual results for the second time, a situation described as “a total and utter shambles”.Mike Ashley’s retail conglomerate was originally due to release the results on 18 July but, shortly beforehand, announced a delay until at least 26 July, saying its auditors needed more time to sign off the accounts.On Wednesday, the company said the report would be published on Friday. Company results usually come out at 7am, but by 8am on Friday, when the stock market opened, the results were still missing, all planned calls with the media and analysts were cancelled and a presentation to investors at the retailer’s London head office was scrapped.A spokesman for Sports Direct said: “Unfortunately we are still finalising preliminary results. We anticipate that our annual results will still be released today, with a presentation to follow.”The company then issued updates at midday and 2pm, each time saying it was still finalising the report. The latest update is due at 4pm.&nbspSports Direct shares seesawed during the day, falling in response to every update from the company. By 2.50pm, they were down 4&nbspper cent on the day.&nbspCreated with Sketch. Show all 9Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.According to the Which? High Street survey 201929 8. House of FraserHomebase has recently dropped the Bunnings association from its storesAccording to the Which? High Street survey 201929 8. House of FraserHomebase has recently dropped the Bunnings association from its storesThe postponed set of results is of particular interest to investors as it will provide an update on House of Fraser, which the company bought out of administration for £90m&nbsplast year. In December, Sports Direct said the department store made a loss of £31.6m since it was acquired in August.When the company announced the first delay, it cited the complexities of integrating House of Fraser and uncertainty about the business’s future performance as part of the reason.“It not only raises questions about the haphazard way in which the investor relations and finance teams are run, but also could suggest a material problem with the numbers.”Additional reporting by PAOnly the best news in your inboxOnly the best news in your inboxEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. title: love island live meet the parents tommy molly mae curtis maura dumping catch up final
story: IM Subscribe NowIM Subscribe NowCreated with Sketch.IM  Subscribe NowIM  Subscribe NowSubscribe NowSubscribe NowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Try Independent Minds free for 1 monthSee the optionsAs it happened EndedFour couples will now compete for public votes in the Love Island final on MondayClick to followThe Independent CultureAnton and Belle have become the latest couple to be dumped from&nbspLove Island&nbspafter receiving the lowest number of public votes.&nbspAnton was one of the original contestants from this year's series while Belle joined later on. The dumping took place after all of the Islanders received visits from their families in the popular&nbspmeet the parents segment of the series.Here are some of the biggest talking points from the penultimate episode of the series.Once Upon a Time in Hollywood star reveals how she got the role27 films and TV shows that changed names13 relationship lessons we’ve learnt from Love Island this yearAnton and Belle got dumpedNot surprisingly, really, given they were one of the least interesting couples this season.&nbspThe contestants got to see their familiesIn what is always one of the most genuinely moving moments of&nbspLove Island,&nbspmembers of each contestant's family turned up to wish the Islanders good luck for the final, offer words of wisdom and meet their respective partners. Top marks for Curtis's mum, who was incapable of pronouncing Maura's name properly (she kept saying Moira).... which clearly gave Amber and Greg the luck they needed to skip through to the&nbspLove Island&nbspfinal.It's possible that viewers were so grossed out after seeing this moment in the preview that they voted Anton and Belle out together, just to save Belle from the horrors of having to shave her boyfriend's arse.&nbspThe liveblog is now closed:&nbspGood evening, and welcome to tonight's Love Island liveblog. It's the penultimate episode of this year's series, so you can guess how excited I am at the prospect of it being over. About as excited as the Islanders when they get a text, so... very.&nbsp&nbspIn this evening's episode the contestants get to see their families for the first time in ages, which is always pretty emotional (for them, at least). It also means it's meet the parents time, with each contestant introducing their respective partners to mum and dad in the hopes of getting their approval.&nbspHere's a sneak-peek at that 'meet the parents' moment&nbsphttps:twitterLoveIslandstatus1155464500935647232Remember I was talking about what we've learnt from this series of Love Island? Well, our lifestyle desk has rounded up the relationship lessons from this season. Lesson 1. Get your boyfriend to shave his own arse&nbsp&nbsphttps:www.life-styledatinglove-island-2019-relationship-lessons-romance-love-heartbreak-a9023176.htmlOhhhh, Maura's ma is a proper Irish mammy. What a babe.&nbsp&nbspOmg, Curtis's mum can't say Maura.&nbspCurtis and Maura enjoyed meeting the parents. Or so they say.&nbsp&nbspA cuddle from your mammy, that's all you need, says Maura. It's true.So Ovie's brother and his cousin are here. Apparently he was taking some liberties with certain things... But we're not sure what.&nbsp&nbspI love Ovie. I don't know if him and India have really clicked properly but he's probably the best person on the show.&nbsp&nbspAnd India's mum is right in there with you're much better looking in real life. And it gives a hint at what that future could look like: 5G iPhones that use Apple’s own chips.Apple has&nbsplong been rumoured to be working on its first 5G iPhone for 2020, putting it behind competitors including&nbspSamsung. Apple's model&nbspis still expected to arrive next year, but the first of them will likely rely on modem chips made by Qualcomm.But, after that, Apple is expected to use the people and patents it acquired through the Intel acquisition to create new kinds of modems for its own iPhones, in line with what has become a central commitment for the company.Under the deal, about 2,200 Intel employees will join Apple, along with intellectual property, equipment and leases.&nbspApple will then&nbsphave 17,000 wireless technology patents, ranging from cellular communication standards to modems, making it a more powerful player in the global licensing talks that will likely be held by major 5G patent holders such as Huawei Technologies.Created with Sketch.Gadgets and tech news in pictures Show all 25Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Chief engineer of LIFT aircraft Balazs Kerulo demonstrates the company's Hexa personal drone craft in Lago Vista, Texas on June 3 2019225 Project Scarlett to succeed Xbox OneMicrosoft announced Project Scarlett, the successor to the Xbox One, at E3 2019. This is a production preview of the Jaguar I-PACE, which will be revealed next year and on the road in 2018After the deal, Intel will retain the right to develop modems for non-smartphone applications, such as PCs, industrial equipment and self-driving cars.New iPhone line-up said to be revealed in huge new leakModem chips connect devices like the iPhone to wireless data networks, but Apple has always relied on outside suppliers for the part. Intel has positioned itself as the sole source of iPhone modem chips over the past year after Apple got into a prolonged legal fight with previous supplier Qualcomm over patent licensing practices.Apple, based in&nbspCupertino, California,&nbspreached a surprise settlement in April that called for the iPhone to once again use Qualcomm modem chips. Within hours, Intel said it would quit the smartphone modem business.Apple’s acquisitions have mostly been much smaller companies, making the Intel deal its second-largest ever after its $3.2bn purchase of Beats Electronics in 2014.The deal with Intel will bolster Apple’s goal to make its own modem chip. Two of Apple’s biggest global rivals – Samsung Electronics and Huawei – already have the ability to self-supply modem chips.Technology news publication The Information last year reported Apple’s efforts to develop its own modem, but the iPhone maker&nbspnever formally acknowledged it. In February, Reuters reported that Apple moved its modem engineering efforts into the same chip design unit that makes the custom processors for its devices, signalling a doubling down on the pursuit of self-designed modem chip.Apple chief executive Tim Cook has also long said the company wants to control its own technological fate – analysts call this&nbspthe “Cook Doctrine”.“We believe that we need to own and control the primary technologies behind the products that we make,” Tim Cook told investors back in 2009.The purchase of Intel’s assets could help Apple meet its aggressive timeline for producing a modem.A person familiar with the matter said Apple plans to use Qualcomm’s modem technology for a 5G iPhone in 2020 but wants to have its own ready for use&nbspby 2021.But any replacement of Qualcomm is likely to happen in phases, this person said, as Apple builds up its ability to ensure that its modems work on all the networks and countries where it sells phones. Ensuring worldwide compatibility is Qualcomm’s historical strength, and Apple might still have to rely on the firm&nbspfor some modems during a transition period to its own devices.“There’s a fierce desire (at Apple) to have independence, but they also realise it has to be done responsibly,” this person said.Apple’s licence deal with Qualcomm lasts six years and its accompanying chip supply agreement could also last that long, said one chip industry veteran who requested anonymity to discuss confidential matters. Apple is likely to continue to use the San Diego firm’s chips in its flagship models even if it phases in its own silicon for lower-end and older models, this person said.Apple has engaged with Taiwan’s Global Unichip Corp, a chip design house in which Apple supplier Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co is an investor, to explore a modem design, but the work is in early stages.“Clearly Apple saw the handwriting on the wall, because they came around and did a deal with Qualcomm,” this person said.Apple declined to comment on its plans, and Qualcomm and Global Unichip did not immediately respond to a request for comment.The most valuable aspect of the Intel deal for Apple could turn out to be patents. To sell a 5G iPhone, Apple will need to strike deals with the major holders of 5G patents, including Nokia, Ericsson, Huawei and Qualcomm. Apple executed a licensing deal with Qualcomm, but it has not disclosed whether it has deals in place with the others.Erick Robinson, a patent attorney who had worked in Qualcomm’s licensing ision in Asia, said the patents could give Apple better leverage in licensing talks.“I don’t think Intel has quite the portfolio that Qualcomm has, but they certainly have a large enough one to impact the valuations when it comes to a cross-licensing deal,” he said. “It’ll save (Apple) a huge chunk of change in cross-licence deals.”Additional reporting by agenciesBe inspired with the latest lifestyle trendsBe inspired with the latest lifestyle trendsEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. story: IM Subscribe NowIM Subscribe NowCreated with Sketch.IM  Subscribe NowIM  Subscribe NowSubscribe NowSubscribe NowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Try Independent Minds free for 1 monthSee the optionsThe effort is inspired by late philanthropist and Microsoft co-founder&nbspPaul AllenClick to followThe IndependentWhen tech entrepreneur Paul Allen returned from a ing trip to Mauritius, he was not a happy man.The billionaire Microsoft co-founder&nbspwas an avid er, and had been privileged to visit some of the best e sites in the world. But his October 2017 visit to the Indian Ocean coincided with the third and largest global coral bleaching. He saw up close&nbspthe devastation that was caused, triggered by a warming planet.“Paul had a deep love of the oceans he would say that being underwater was one of his favourite places in the world,” says Lauren Kickham, director of impact at Vulcan Inc, which Allen established in 1986 to oversee his business and philanthropic interests.“After a trip to one of his favourite e sites, when there had been no coral left, he tasked us with saving the world’s coral reefs.”Allen, who was first diagnosed with Hodgkin&nbsplymphoma in 1982, died last year at the age of 65. But his&nbspdream of&nbspsaving&nbspthe planet’s coral wasn’t forgotten.&nbspA team of satellite mappers, marine scientists and naturalists&nbspbegan&nbspmapping&nbspand monitoring all the world’s reefs – resulting in the&nbspAllen Coral Atlas. At a recent presentation in Seattle, they&nbsprevealed that while they had tracked just 2 per cent of the world’s coral, they&nbsphoped to have completed the task by the end of 2020.Created with Sketch.Coral reefs: Trying to combat climate change damage Show all 25Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Masked Butterflyfish (Chaetodon semilarvatus) swimming over a bommie reef in the Egyptian Red Sea marine reserve of Ras Mohamed, off the southern tip of the Sinai peninsulaRising sea temperatures cause corals to bleach (go white) and dieA giant clam is seen nestled among coral reefs at the Obhor coast, 30 kms north of the Red Sea city of Jeddah425 Coral reef in seychelles that has degradedAfter the reef has died they break up and become rubble. Global warming has in recent years caused colourful coral reefs to bleach and die around the world -- but not in the Gulf of Eilat, or Aqaba, part of the northern Red Sea. At the Interuniversity Institute for Marine Sciences in southern Israeli resort city Eilat, dozens of aquariums have been lined up in rows just off the Red Sea shore containing samples of local coralsfish swimming off the coast of Egypt's Red Sea resort of HurghadaThe global coral map is updated every day, and uses advances in artificial intelligence to issue alerts when reef health declines. This monitoring system&nbspmeans that when&nbspcrises hit, such as bleaching&nbspor shipwrecks, local authorities and conservationists will be able to act quickly.“This is game-changing,” says Greg Asner, director of Arizona State University’s centre for global discovery and conservation science. “I’ve been doing this for 25 years. Until two years ago, we would get an image and then we’d unpack it, and spend&nbspmonths and even years trying to determine what was going on on the sea floor.”Asner says&nbspthere was a recent&nbspincident in one of the northern areas of the Marshall Islands where a tanker&nbspran aground, a long way from where the authorities were based in the south.“The first image of this happening was from our project,” he says. “I had colleagues there, and they took the picture to the environmental agency,&nbspand they found that the tanker had spilled a large amount of fuel oil. The process for them was how them to mitigate that. But we had the image, the next day.”He says anywhere up to a billion&nbsppeople depend directly on coral for their livelihoods, but that even larger numbers benefit from their association with fisheries and the breaking of storm surges.&nbspA report published earlier this year by the UN about challenges to bioersity&nbspwarned that up to a million&nbspspecies were threatened with extinction. It said around one third of reef-forming corals were at risk.“Bioersity and nature’s contributions to people are our common heritage and humanity’s most important life-supporting safety net,” warned Sandra&nbspDiaz, a renowned Argentine ecologist who co-chaired the report. “But our safety net is stretched almost to breaking point.”The images used by Asner and others&nbspare provided by Planet Labs, a California-based company that operates 120 satellites&nbspto provide almost real-time images. The new images provided by the latest generation of satellites – lighter, smaller and cheaper – means Planet Labs&nbspcan detect deforestation, the growth of cities, sea ice, and even the spread of camps for&nbsprefugees or&nbspinternally displaced people.Andrew Zolli, the company’s vice president of global impact, says the team is fond of saying: “You can’t save something you cannot see.”&nbsp“These problems tend to be remote from our everyday experience,” he says.&nbsp“We hand these data sets to scientists,” Zolli&nbspadds. “The challenge is how to turn big data into action.”The map being produced for the coral atlas&nbspwill comprise&nbspthe&nbsphighest resolution images of the world’s reefs seen so far.“What we know about the coral reefs is&nbspthat they are under tremendous stress, specifically from climate change and human development. Yet&nbspno high-resolution&nbspmap of the world’s coral reefs exists,” he says.“Less than a hundredth&nbspof 1 per cent of the world’s reefs are actively monitored for change, and when they are, they’re monitored using methods that would have been familiar to the Wright brothers. People go up in planes and literally estimate the extent of things such as coral bleaching.”He adds: “We’re using an early 20th-century solution to deal with a global&nbsp21st-century problem, and we’re failing at it badly.”Allen, who died last October and was said to have a fortune of more than $20bn&nbsp(£16bn) at the time of death, did not have an entirely seamless relationship with the oceans. In January 2016, it was reported that one of his yachts, the 303ft MV Tatoosh, unintentionally destroyed a large part of a coral reef in the Cayman Islands&nbspwith its anchor chain.Coral gardening: The front line in the fight against climate change?Endangered green turtles increasing in numbers, study showsAustralia floods pose ‘freshwater bleaching’ risk to vulnerable coralsRuth Gates: Marine biologist who worked on breeding a ‘super coral’A spokesperson for Vulcan said&nbspat the time that Allen was not in the Caribbean when the incident took place, and questioned the reported scale of the damage the accident caused.A Vulcan spokesperson told The Independent: “It was never determined that the coral injury in the Cayman Islands was caused by the Tatoosh, as there was a long history of incidents in that location. Regardless, in 2016, Vulcan quickly commissioned leading experts in coral and reef restoration to rebuild, protect and preserve the local ecosystem for generations to come.”Helen Fox has the task of using the data produced by the Allen-inspired project and working with local communities. She says sometimes&nbspthey are able to piggyback on existing projects sometimes they start new initiatives.&nbspThey also work with conservationists and students to e and take images pegged to a GPS tracker, to help validate the maps produced the satellites.Fox, a senior director at the National Geographic Society, says the goal “is to have a network of engaged users who can receive alerts if there are bleaching events or ship groundings”.She says the unique aspect of the project is the speed with which it provides images, matched with its global scale.“We’ve never had anything like that before,” she says. “It just opens up whole new avenues of possibility.”Only the best news in your inboxOnly the best news in your inboxEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. title: sky mobile three huawei 5g phone security china
story: IM Subscribe NowIM Subscribe NowCreated with Sketch.IM  Subscribe NowIM  Subscribe NowSubscribe NowSubscribe NowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Try Independent Minds free for 1 monthSee the optionsO2, EE and others have left the Chine company's handsets out of their own 5G offeringsClick to followThe IndependentSky Mobile and Three have become the first mobile operators to promise Huawei’s smartphones on the UK’s new 5G mobile networks, despite security fears about the Chinese technology company.Huawei’s Mate 20 X 5G device is one of a limited number of phones capable of utilising 5G, the fifth generation of mobile networking technology that allows significantly faster connections than its predecessors.The US has said Huawei’s equipment could be used by China to spy on users, an allegation the Chinese company denies.Sky Mobile said it will offer Mate 20 X 5G and Samsung's Galaxy S10 5G when it launches its 5G network in November.Three began offering the Mate 20 on Friday ahead of the roll-out of its 5G offering later this year. Its customers will pay the same for 5G as they currently pay for 4G, the company announced on Friday.Created with Sketch.Europe replicated in Huawei City, China Show all 8Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.18 Karl Theodor Bridge in Heidelberg, Germany28 Replica Karl Theodor Bridge in Huawei City, China48 Replica Heidelberg in Huawei City, China68 Replica Cesky Krumlov in Huawei City, China88 Replica Heidelberg in Huawei City, China18 Karl Theodor Bridge in Heidelberg, Germany28 Replica Karl Theodor Bridge in Huawei City, China48 Replica Heidelberg in Huawei City, China68 Replica Cesky Krumlov in Huawei City, China88 Replica Heidelberg in Huawei City, ChinaOther networks, including EE, Vodafone and O2, have left Huawei’s handset out of their 5G launches.America and a number of other nations have banned Huawei equipment from being used in their 5G networks.On Monday, the UK government delayed the final decision on whether to ban the firm from the country’s 5G networks.Currently, Huawei’s equipment is allowed to be used for “non-core” parts of the UK’s 5G infrastructure and there is nothing to prevent mobile networks from offering the company’s smartphones.“Core” parts of the network include those that check device IDs are checked and decide how to route voice calls and data.Last month Huawei's UK boss, Anson Zhang, said the company had not changed anything about its devices in response to US sanctions and scrutiny in the UK.His comments came weeks after former UK spy chief Sir Richard Dearlove warned that Huawei’s involvement in the 5G network represents a “potential security risk to the UK”.The former MI6 director described reports that the government is ready to permit Huawei to bid for “non-core” elements of the project as “deeply worrying”.Only the best news in your inboxOnly the best news in your inboxEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. title: sports direct annual results delay mike ashley house fraser
story: IM Subscribe NowIM Subscribe NowCreated with Sketch.IM  Subscribe NowIM  Subscribe NowSubscribe NowSubscribe NowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Try Independent Minds free for 1 monthSee the optionsThe report, due to update investors on the performance of House of Fraser, was originally scheduled for 18 JulyClick to followThe IndependentSports Direct has postponed the publication of its latest annual results for the second time, a situation described as “a total and utter shambles”.Mike Ashley’s retail conglomerate was originally due to release the results on 18 July but, shortly beforehand, announced a delay until at least 26 July, saying its auditors needed more time to sign off the accounts.On Wednesday, the company said the report would be published on Friday. Company results usually come out at 7am, but by 8am on Friday, when the stock market opened, the results were still missing, all planned calls with the media and analysts were cancelled and a presentation to investors at the retailer’s London head office was scrapped.A spokesman for Sports Direct said: “Unfortunately we are still finalising preliminary results. We anticipate that our annual results will still be released today, with a presentation to follow.”The company then issued updates at midday and 2pm, each time saying it was still finalising the report. The latest update is due at 4pm.&nbspSports Direct shares seesawed during the day, falling in response to every update from the company. By 2.50pm, they were down 4&nbspper cent on the day.&nbspCreated with Sketch. Show all 9Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.According to the Which? High Street survey 201929 8. House of FraserHomebase has recently dropped the Bunnings association from its storesAccording to the Which? High Street survey 201929 8. House of FraserHomebase has recently dropped the Bunnings association from its storesThe postponed set of results is of particular interest to investors as it will provide an update on House of Fraser, which the company bought out of administration for £90m&nbsplast year. In December, Sports Direct said the department store made a loss of £31.6m since it was acquired in August.When the company announced the first delay, it cited the complexities of integrating House of Fraser and uncertainty about the business’s future performance as part of the reason.“It not only raises questions about the haphazard way in which the investor relations and finance teams are run, but also could suggest a material problem with the numbers.”Additional reporting by PAOnly the best news in your inboxOnly the best news in your inboxEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. A local by-election was triggered when Peterborough's former MP Fiona Onasanya was sacked by her constituents in the first successful re-call petition prompting a by-election.By-election votes are counted at the KingsGate Centre in Peterborough.She added that she went to check if anyone had been injured but found no one inside.Although Dyfed Powys Police reportedly told Ms Charles they were aware of the bus&nbspand had sent someone to investigate it, no official statement has been released on the incident.A local vehicle recovery company said they were asked to tow the vehicle to Cardiff on Sunday morning.What does the Remain parties’ pact for the Brecon by-election mean?Although Brexit Party candidate Des Parkinson said the bus broke down last night, Derek Jeffs, a local removal company boss, told Wales Online that he saw the bus stranded on Saturday afternoon.“It looked as if the bus had turned into the layby but there wasn’t enough room to turn it around. However, the driver couldn’t reverse because the road dipped down,” he said.“The driver was still in the cab and he didn’t look best pleased.”The Brexit Party are currently attempting to win their first parliamentary seat in the Brecon and Radnorshire by-election.The by-election was triggered when Chris Davies, a Conservative MP, was recalled after he pleaded guilty in March to claiming false expenses.The Liberal Democrats are favourites to win the election, with the Brexit Party predicted to challenge the Conservatives for second place.A victory for either the Liberal Democrats or the Brexit Party would reduce Boris Johnson’s majority in the House of Commons to just one MP.Voters in the constituency will go to the polls on Thursday.brecon and radnorshire by-election&nbsp|&nbspThe latest news on Brexit, politics and beyond direct to your inboxThe latest news on Brexit, politics and beyond direct to your inboxEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. followThe Independent USA swarm of winged insects enveloped a pyramid: sound familiar?An invasion of pallid-winged grasshoppers descended on Las Vegas this week, taking over the Strip and several of the city’s most popular tourist spots, including the night skies above the Luxor hotel and casino.The resort, a 30-story pyramid inspired by ancient Egypt, says that its Sky Beam, a powerful column of light issuing nightly from the peak of the pyramid, can be seen by airline pilots as far away as Los Angeles.But the beam has also become a magnet for grasshoppers, which experts say are drawn to ultraviolet light and could linger in Las Vegas for weeks.“What we would consider the white lights are the ones we would consider more attractive to them,” Jeff Knight, an entomologist with the Nevada story: IM Subscribe NowIM Subscribe NowCreated with Sketch.IM  Subscribe NowIM  Subscribe NowSubscribe NowSubscribe NowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Try Independent Minds free for 1 monthSee the optionsExclusive: Father of crew member&nbspsaid he spoke to his son&nbspearly Thursday, urged all governments involved to help bring his loved one homeClick to followThe IndependentThe distraught families of the crewmen onboard a British-flagged tanker seized by Iran have made first contact with their loved ones but&nbspexpressed fears they have no idea&nbspwhen they might be released.&nbspIndian national T.V. Pappachan, 58, whose son Dijo, 26, is one of 23 seamen onboard, told The Independent he felt “huge relief” he received a short phone call from Dijo&nbspin the early hours of Thursday morning.&nbspThe crew have been held incommunicado since the Stena Impero was seized by Iran’s Revolutionary Guard on Friday amid heightened tensions between Tehran and the UK since the seizure of Iranian supertanker Grace 1&nbspoff the coast of Gibraltar earlier this month.Speaking from Kerala, India, Mr Pappachan&nbspsaid that&nbspDijo&nbspand the others appeared “calm” and safe, but had not been told when they would be permitted to go home.&nbspThe owners of the tanker also confirmed that crew members had been able to speak directly to their families, saying in a statement on Thursday they were continuing to “hold dialogue” with all governments and authorities involved.Mr Pappachan said the family was pinning hope on the ongoing diplomatic efforts to ensure a speedy return of his son, who he last spoke to just hours before the dramatic capture.&nbsp​We feel much better now after hearing from Dijo, that he&nbspis being fed properly and treated well. title: work ban hot temperatures labour
story: Leader Jeremy Corbyn has vowed to put an end to sweaty workplaces.Employers will have to introduce air conditioning, extra breaks and let staff turn up in shorts and T shirts under the plan.And workers doing physically tough jobs will get to down tools over C .Shadow business minister Laura Pidcock said: “As we’re all being reminded this week, working in hot conditions is really uncomfortable, often stressful and it makes us less productive and even ill.“Plus it’s often the lowest paid and most insecure workers who suffer the most.Labour said global warming means sweltering heatwaves are here to stay.But their proposals risk fuelling the problem by forcing employers to install energy-guzzling air conditioning units – which is adding to climate change.The free-market think-tank, the Institute of Economic Affairs, said Labour is just chasing headlines and that employers already have to provide a ‘reasonable’ temperature.The IEA’s Andy Mayer said: “Labour’s proposal, while eye-catching, would make no one better off, but instead reduce the flexibility of employers to manage those risks.“What is appropriate for the socialist book store in Islington is not appropriate for a foundry in Sheffield or kiln in Stoke.“Micro-legislating in this way will simply add to their costs and risk unemployment.”Britain has been baking in a heatwave this week, with temperatures set to soar to C  today.GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: opinion eu waives border checks ireland
story: Remainers see their dream of a second referendum, or cancelling Brexit, dying.Labour and its media cheerleaders are terried that this Tory leader could rip them apart. One Labour MP predicts Boris will “wipe the floor” with Corbyn.Panic has set in with Irish leader Leo Varadkar too, ramping up his rhetoric now we have a PM who means business.No Deal will cause Dublin such chaos that the EU intends to let them waive border checks. So much for the “backstop” being vital to avoid a hard border. In the end they’ll just make checks away from the border, as Eurosceptics said.Our new Cabinet, meanwhile, fizzes with energy and resolve. Long may it last.And while a suicide squad of Tory Remoaners may still fancy forcing an election to avoid No Deal, that threat looks far less potent than a week ago.WE despair of our police.Yes, they are short-staffed. That is obviously partly to blame for kne crime soaring to record highs. We back the , cops the Tories aim to recruit.But then “hard-pressed” bobbies build a huge tower of hats in a juvenile social media contest. And the Met commissions a spray-painter to daub a nick with cartoons bearing banal messages.Some forces have given up on burglaries, blaming cuts. The Met often seems to have given up on even more serious crime. Yet the stunts and virtue-signalling keep coming. And police chiefs seem too dim to grasp how bad it looks.New policing minister Kit Malthouse is focused on recruitment. But he must also lay down the law about ato basic crime-fighting and detection.Plus a ban on social media posts that do nothing for the public but enrage it.IT began with Jews. Now Labour’s race hatred extends to black and ethnic minority people who vote the “wrong” way.Look how they are targeting BAME Cabinet members. Clive Lewis MP, an acolyte of anti-Semite Corbyn, tells black Tory chairman James Cleverly he “sold his soul” to serve “a racist PM”.A Corbynite “journalist” says politicians like Sajid Javid and Priti Patel are “no longer a person of colour. They are a turncoat of colour”.Labour has no time for BAME people it cannot deploy as victims of Tory “oppression”. If they reject that victimhood, vote Conservative or, worse, have the talent to reach the top of a Tory Government, they are not “properly” BAME.Such is the poison of “identity politics” spread by Corbyn and his cult of hate-filled halfwits.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: bob geldof gary lineker tony blair cant stop brexit
story: Not the democracy-denying weasels in the House of Commons. Not the civil service nor the BBC. Not the House of Lords. Not Tony Blair and John Major and Gordon Brown. Not the Labour Party.And not the combined might of Bob Geldof, Gary Lineker and the bloke who screams, “STOP BREXIT!” in Parliament Square from dawn till dusk.Oh how they all loathed Brexit and everyone who voted for it! They truly believed that those of us who voted to leave the European Union were all thick, racist bigots.There was never any real attempt to change the minds of the .million. There were only sneers, jeers and smears — and the full might of the British establishment committed to stop Brexit from ever happening.Brexit — a true Brexit — has not always seemed inevitable. There have been times over the past few years when the EU looked like the Hotel Calornia, where you can check out but you can never leave.But in the end, it did not matter what they wanted — the elite, the ones with power, the pampered factions of the British establishment, who are totally accustomed to getting their way.Because once the British people had made their democratic decision, Brexit was ALWAYS going to happen in the end.It is more than three years since the nation decided to leave the European Union.But it is only a matter of days that we have had a Prime Minister who actually believes in Brexit.Boris has electried Britain with his vision of a bright, shining future for our country outside of the  rotting EU empire.My heart says Prime Minister Johnson will get Brexit done. So do the bookies.He will probably need a General Election before Christmas to shake up the Parliamentary numbers, but Boris will make it happen.ButBoris can’t do it, then somebody  will make Brexit happen.Brexit is bigger than Boris. Democracy is more important than any one politician.And let the record state: It would have worked the other way around.If the British people had decided in the summer of  that we were staying in the European Union, then no amount of bitching from Brussels-loathing old gits such as myself would have mattered a damn.We would have stayed in the EU for a generation. Our current national debate is not ultimately about leaving or remaining.It is about democracy. And democracy still matters here.Democracy is deep in the British DNA, far deeper than in all those European nations where they have the national memory of a jackboot resting on their throats, far deeper than in all those countries where they have been invaded, occupied and tormented by tyrants.That is why the British establishment, in the end, could not veto Brexit. Sorry, chaps, you can’t dial down democracy. You can’t cancel the will of the people. Not in THIS country.The people decidedIn the end, democracy would not be denied. They could not reverse, overrule or cancel a referendum result in a country that has not been invaded for one thousand years.The will of the establishment — all those ex-Prime Ministers, all those well-heeled big shots, all those Right Honourable members and ermine-clad Lords, all those BBC executives, all those crisp sellers and ex-members of the Boomtown Rats — did not matter more than the will of the people.There is a historical inevitability about this country leaving the EU because, quite simply, it is what the people decided.And no matter what the establishment may believe, the people in this country are not their servants.Our great country is a democracy.Now and for ever, the people are the masters.And that makes Brexit unstoppable.NEW Liberal Democrats leader Jo Swinson wants a second referendum  but admits she would still campaign to keep the UK in the EU evenwe voted to leave yet again.Oh Jo. You may be a liberal. But you are not much of a democrat.Now the cops have dragged Fadi out, kicking and screaming.The property has been secured but worried neighbours say that Fadi could easily get back in with  a ladder.Oh Fadi, you don’t need a ladder. You need a job.And to stop poncing off the generosity of George Michael.THE Conservative Party is now the true representative of the working class.Lefty loons sneer that the Tories are as riven by racism as Labour, that the anti- Semitism that is rotting Labour is matched by Islamophobia in the Conservative Party.But a political party that disliked Muslims would not appoint the son of a Pakistani bus driver to one of the great offices of state – Sajid Javid as Chancellor of the Exchequer.And a party that was inherently racist would not promote Priti Patel – the daughter of Hindu refugees – to Home Secretary.And what a joy to see Esther McVey – who spent part of her young le in a Barnardo’s care home –to the Cabinet as Housing Minister.We may have an Old Etonian as PM, but the Tories are the party of the people now.I AM starting to look forward to an autumn general election.The most devastating put-down that our new Prime Minister made in the House of Commons was the one aimed at John McDonnell.“The Shadow Chancellor!” said Boris, jabbing a finger at McDonnell’s florid, furious face. “Sacked by Ken Livingstone for being too left-wing . . .  sacked for fabricating a budget!”Like every bully who ever lived, McDonnell can dish it out but he sure can’t take it.Jeremy Corbyn suddenly looks more like a candidate for a care home than  Downing Street. But McDonnell could prove to be an even bigger electoral liability to Labour.If that autumn general election comes, the voters must look at McDonnell and ask themselves: Should I really trust a miserable old Marxist with my wallet Perhaps we should send that aid to countries that are not sending rockets to the Moon.Or better still, help the needy in our own country.THE new series of Strictly will be graced by another of the remarkable Mabuse sisters – Motsi Mabuse, Oti’s big sister, who is replacing Darcey Bussell when the th series starts in September.There have been fears expressed that the new judge might favour her kid sister.I can’t think of anything less likely.The three Mabuse sisters – Oti, Motsi and middle sister Phemelo – all danced their way out of riot-torn, apartheid-riven South Africa.They are all dancing pros to the core of their being.Bet your last sequin that Motsi will not do Oti any favours.HOW sad to hear that  Rutger Hauer has died at the age of . Rutger gave one of cinema’s greatest  performances as the android Roy in  Ridley Scott’s  masterpiece, Blade Runner. Despite looking like Billy Idol’s butch big brother.THERE is an allegedly “popcorn-dropping moment” at the start of the next James Bond film when – after Bond retires – a senior spook says: “Come in, .”And Lashana Lynch – black, beautul and female – walks into the room.But is this really such a shocker In the increasingly “woke” world of Bond, it would have been far more surprisingthe new  was revealed to be a middle-aged white bloke with a pack of Viagra in his tuxedo.The Bond films now forbid the term “Bond girls” being used on set. Daniel Craig calls  a “misogynist”.Bond is certainly promiscuous, reluctant to commit and possibly a sex addict. But suggesting he hates women is just stupid.Everyone involved with Bond  – the next film – seems acutely embarrassed about associating with the sexist old dinosaur.Naomie Harris – so brilliant as the new incarnation of Miss Moneypenny – says: “The Bond of old, his days are numbered.”Why so defensive  The greatest James Bond film of all time – Skyfall, directed by Sam Mendes – showed a  who was being overtaken by time, his bones creaking, his body aching and his shooting skills not what they once were.But Mendes did not have the craven virtue-signalling, political correctness that currently infests the James Bond franchise.For more than half a century, millions have looked to  for iconic thrills, spills and entertainment. Sexy, witty, escapist fun.If you want us to drop our popcorn, then make a James Bond film like that.Because  is becoming licensed to kill joy.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: twitter hoax footballer gay
story: The account was thought to be run by a Championship footballer who intended to come out as gay before it emerged it was possibly a hoax.If you’re not a football fan, you might not realise what a big deal this would have beenit had been real.Liam Davis, currently the only openly gay footballer still playing professionally in the UK, came out ten years ago.Before that, the previous professional footballer to come out as gay while playing on these shores was Justin Fashanu in . He then took his own le eight years later.Given that one in  of the population identies as gay, this doesn’t exactly seem representative.And that’s probably why @FootballerGay’s account racked up so much support so quickly.The account’s profile said the player was a “proud gay man”. He posted numerous tweets saying his club had been informed of his decision to come out and had been supportive. He tweeted saying that on July  he would reveal his identity.But instead, the account was deleted a couple of days ago. And shortly before that, the bio on the account was changed to read: “I thought I was strong enough. I’m not.”Although his tweets had messages of support from people such as Gary Lineker, lots of other people doubted the authenticity of the account.That includes my husband, an ex professional footballer.His view is that these days no one, from other players to the club, would caresomeone were gay.He should know. He played with Justin Fashanu and says no one in the dressing room had a problem with Justin being gay and he wasn’t treated any dferently to anyone .Still, outside the dressing room, he was singled out.Just one example is the time the owner of the opposing team called him a faggot from the sidelines.Fashanusprinted towards this guy, who got so scared he locked himself in the Press box.Fashanu kicked the door down to find the guy pleading, crying and denying he said anything. Justin could look after himself. But that kind of thing took its toll.Although we’ve moved on since , hearing stories such as that does make you realise why some footballers might think twice about coming out.I don’t carethe Twitter account was real or not. After all, who someone sleeps with is none of my business. Butsomeone wants to come out to the world, it is a terrible state of affairshe thinks he needs to be strong and “brave” to do so.And the reality is that attitudes towards a lot of things have changed over the past couple of decades.I remember when I turned up at the Director’s Box of an away game when I first took over at Birmingham City Football Club in .When I asked where the boardroom was I was told that director’s wives go in the ladies room. When I mentioned that I was the managing director the old boy on the desk put his glasses on, looked at me and said: “Oh yes, you’re that woman . . . stay here and I will find out what to do with you.”Because, at that point, women where banned from entering the boardrooms.That was the first door I ever kicked down. So I know in a very small way how being the first and being dferent to everyone  in football feels.Nowadays I am proud to say there are so many talented women running clubs. And I like to think we have moved on enough that no one would bat an eyelid at a gay footballer.Still, the football world can be a fairly intolerant place for anyone who is anything close to a minority.Maybe it’s the case that until we create a tolerant, accepting environment and culture then footballers won’t feel safe enough to come out.But which will comes first: that . . . or, someone like this being brave enough to admit they are gay and face the possible backlash.Only time will tell.And what I’d really like to see is a football culture in which someone’s sexual orientation really is neither here nor there.DID anyone  wince looking at the photo of the man intercepting his girlfriend’s moment of glory when she was being awarded her degree – to drop down on one knee and propose I guess Edgaras Averbuchas saw it as a romantic gesture but to the onlooker it was just a bit, well, selfish.For a start it looked like he couldn’t bear to let Agne Banuskeviciute have her moment in the sun so muscled in. He attempted to eclipse her huge achievement and make it all about him.Plus, he put her in a very dficult position. I mean, whatAgne wanted to say no Why didn’t he just let her graduate and then ask her in the evening to marry him But also, Agne wasn’t the only person graduating that day – I wonder how everyone  felt about having their big day overshadowed by this big “romantic” gesture Sorry to say that this does not bode well for the relationship.And my advice to this young woman would be to run while you still have the chance and find someone content to allow you to be successful in your own right.[boxout featured-image introI LOVED reading about Mackenzie O’Neill, the -year-old from Canterbury, Kent, who found himself having a bit of a kickabout with Lionel Messi on a Caribbean beach – the stuff that dreams are made of for some kids.]This is the kind of memory that never goes away, but it’s not only children that live for a moment like this. My husband, himself a professional footballer, played on the beach with Diego Maradona about five years agoand he still can’t stop talking about it.[ boxout]KEVIN CASH, once hailed as one of Britain’s most successful property tycoons with a fortune of £million, was declared bankrupt last July with debts of £million.So it is no surprise that he and fourth we Carla are now going to have to make a few changes to their lives.But when you hear that they used to spend £,-a-month on groceries and “housekeeping”, it becomes clear how hard it might be for them to get used to bankruptcy and shopping, presumably, at Lidl.What on earth are they buying  Gold bars to eat Now they’ll be shopping in the bargain bin.As Arsene Wenger used to say about Arsenal’s performances: “One day caviar, and the next cabbage.”WHATEVER you think about Theresa May, no one could deny that she is driven by a sense of duty to the country.So it’s no surprise that she has shed a tear once or twice over the past couple of very dficult months of dashed hopes and disappointments.But what has struck me when she’s been caught crying on camera is how quick people seem to be to triumph over what they see as a sign of weakness.Meanwhile,a man in a position of responsibility is seen to show emotion or shed a tear, he is seen as admirable, noble and passionate.I mean, it’s one thing wearing one in bed, it’s another thing altogether wearing it in bed with a new girlfriend.But to do so on national TV Well, all I can say is, I hope he wasn’t in his socks as well.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. I think this is taking Malawians for granted.What is Mrs Chimulirenji doing in the UK  Escorting a friend to the UK asthey are going to Chinakanaka market We are being taken for granted as Malawians.Protesters have taken to the streets demanding that Mrs Mutharikathe money spent on the trip.They are also alleging fraud in the countrys recent elections in May, which resulted in Peter Mutharika retaining power.Malawi was a former British colony known as Nyasaland and has received billions of pounds in aid from the UK over the past  years.Mrs Mutharika came to the UK see her son Tadikira Mafubza – the president’s stepson – receive his masters degree in civil engineering. from the University of Greenwich in Kent on Thursday.The Malawian authorities admit it was a allegations over spending spree to fund her private trip to the UK.The country has long suffered political instability over corruption accusations.Last year, Malawis president denied allegations of corruption, including claims he was given bribes of more than £million for a contract to supply food to the police.In May, former International Development Secretary Rory Stewart presented Malawi as an example of the failure of the UKs foreign aid policy.He said: The Government has spent something in the region of £. billion over the past  years and Malawi is,anything, poorer than it was when we started.Britain’s Department for International Developmentspends about £million each year in Malawi.The country has a population of about  million an average annual wage of £, making it one of the agriculture and the election crisis lead to stagnation in growth.A DFID spokesman said: No UK aid funding is given directly to the government of Malawi, and no UK aid has been spent on this visit.We ensure our support through trusted partners delivers value for money for UK taxpayers and transforms the lives of the poorest people, with , children in Malawi getting a good education as a result of UK aid.

story: Crews were called to Sheringham beach in Norfolk at around .pm today after the man became trapped in rocks near the shore.Rising tides saw the man become slowly submerged up to neck height in the water.HM Coastguard was forced to hold the mans head above the surface before eventually freeing him shortly before .pm.The man was given breathing equipment and a lejacket as crews battled to release him.He suffered only minor injuries and the child was unhurt in the incident.Firefighters and paramedics were also called to the scene along with Coastguard and RNLI Leboat crews.Stuart Facey, who was walking his dog when the Coastguard arrived, said: I saw someone obviously stuck in the rocks, it was high tide and water was coming over him so it was a very scary situation.Ive seen people climb into the cavities in the rocks and the problem is that evenyou are able to move a rock to free someone who is stuck, another can fall into its place it can be a le or death situation.Zach Pedley from HM Coastguard said at the time of the incident: This is a very frightening experience for this man.Thankfully someone knew to call  and ask for the Coastguard which meant we could send the right response immediately.Everyone is working together at the scene to keep him calm and safe as we effect the rescue.A statement on the Coastguard website said: HM Coastguard is currently coordinating the rescue of a man who got his leg trapped in the rocks while the tide was coming in.Although the water has come in a fair way, the emergency responders are on scene helping to reassure him and holding his head about the water. title: boris embarks whirlwind uk tour
story: NewsBoris Johnson kicks off snap UK tour and £bn spending blitz for no-deal BrexitMinisters will hold daily crisis meetings amid plans for a massive No Deal public information campaignShareCommentsByPippa CrerarDaily Mirror Political Editor:,  JUL Updated:,  JUL NewsBoris Johnson is off on a whirlwind tour of Britain "Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailBoris Johnson is set to announce a £bn boost for No Deal Brexit planning this week - despite saying there was just a “million to one chance” of leaving the EU in a chaotic departure.  The new Prime Minister will today embark on a whirlwind tour to the four corners of the United Kingdom in a desperate bid to prevent the break-up of the Union as a result.  It came as Downing Street announced that a team of pro-Brexit cabinet ministers will hold daily crisis meetings to prepare for a damaging no-deal departure. The spending blitz includes one of the country’s “biggest ever” public information campaigns to make sure iniduals and businesses are ready for any outcome.    Cabinet Office Minister Michael Gove said the Government is “operating on the assumption” that Britain will leave the EU without a deal. But Mr Johnson faces staunch opposition to his hardline Brexit plans from within his own party - as senior Tory MPs work cross-party to try to stop him.   Ahead of his trip to Scotland today, Scots Tory leader Ruth Davidson issued a defiant challenge to the PM: “I don’t think the Government should pursue a no-deal Brexit and,it comes to it, I won’t support it.” She warned that her party was free to pursue its own Brexit stance “independently of government”, signalling she is ready to defy the new PM less than a week into office. Mr Johnson, deeply unpopular North of the Border, has been warned that he risks breaking up the UKwe crash out without a deal.    Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn warned he would do “everything” to prevent it including tabling a no confidence motion in the Government. But opponents of the PM’s hardline approach fear that “turbo-charging” no-deal preparations shows he is serious about that course, with all the risks it carries for the economy and the Union.  They believe he is trying to shore up support for no-deal across the country to put pressure on rebel MPs - and prove to the EU he is serious about leaving on October  “no s or buts’. It also dramatically heightens the chances of the new PM suspending Parliament or calling a snap election to force it through.  The previous Government had already allocated more than £bn on getting the country ready for a chaotic departure. New Chancellor Sajid Javid revealed yesterday he had already tasked Treasury officials with finding which areas needed more cash.  “And next week I will be announcing signicant extra funding to do just that,” he added. Government sources indicated this would be at least £bn.   No  revealed that senior ministers - led by Michael Gove - will meet daily from Tuesday in the COBRA room where the Government holds its emergency planning meetings.

title: home secretarypritipatel plans immigration crackdown
story: NewsHome Secretary Priti Patel plans immigration crackdown after BrexitShe wants to toughen up the rules whether or not theres a Brexit dealShareByNicola BartlettPolitical Correspondent:,  JUL Updated:,  JUL NewsPriti Patel has already announced changes "Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailHome Secretary Priti Patel has outlined her plans to toughen up the UKaposs immigration system whether or not the UK leaves the EU with a deal.Ms Patel, who has consistently supported harsher rules, has vowed to seize the once-in-a-letime opportunity offered by Brexit to enact Boris Johnsonaposs radical shake-up.The Prime Minister has already committed to a radical rewrite of the rules in his first speech in the job. And his new Home Secretary confirmed she would be urgently commissioning the Migration Advisory Committee to review Australiaaposs points-based system.    Writing in the Mail on Sunday, she added: The current migration system means we have to give an automatic right of access to all EU nationals. In future, we will decide who we give preference to, so we can ensure we are able to attract the most talented and skilled from other parts of the world. The new Home Secretary also vowed to ensure a strong border to help keep out terrorists and criminals, and said all prospective migrants would be checked for criminal records. Ms Patel insisted that a skills-based approach would boost the economy.    We must seize the once-in-a-letime opportunity offered by the end of free movement, she wrote. Free from the shackles of the EU - and an automatic right of entry for their citizens, with or without work - we will be able to give the type of preference to brilliant scientists, academics and highly skilled workers that we want to see more of. But her record, which includes voting for stricter measures for asylum seekers, suggests the crackdown could form part of a wider programme of harsher measures on immigration. Mr Johnson made no secret of his desire for an Australian-style points-based immigration system during the Tory leadership contest. He set out his proposals as part of his wide-ranging first Commons speech as Prime Minister, saying: No-one believes more strongly than me in the benefits of migration to our country. But I am clear that our immigration system must change.

title: vengeful theresa go thatcher boris
story: NewsVengeful Theresa May to go Thatcher on Boris Johnson using backbench influenceEXCLUSIVE: Insiders say that with a slim majority, Mr Johnson will struggle to get legislation through and May will have more controlShareCommentsByKeir Mudie:,  JUL Updated:,  JUL NewsTheresa May may have a surprise sting in the tail for the new PM "Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email The biggest threat to new Prime Minister Boris Johnson’s premiership is Theresa May , say Westminster insiders.The former PM is poised to take her place on the backbenches when Parliament s – and many believe she will “do a Thatcher” by running things from behind the scenes. Insiders say that with a slim majority, Mr Johnson will struggle to get legislation through.And with Brexit looming, Mrs May’s ­influence on the backbenches will be crucial.Mr Johnson killed off her deal this week and said the UK was prepared to leave without one.    And, in a move that infuriated her inner circle, he pressed for the backstop to be scrapped. Sources say she is making plans to set traps for the new leader. Her first step was consolidating her power base. Hours after leaving Downing Street, she watched England’s cricketers with two of her since-sacked ministers, David Gauke and Greg Clark, and ex-chief of staff Gavin Barwell. Earlier, Mrs May was spotted wearing a gold pebble bracelet that bore a striking resemblance to one that belonged to Mrs Thatcher.    This prompted speculation she had been the secret bidder at an auction in May. One Whitehall source said: “May might have bought ­Thatcher’s bracelet but she also plans to copy what she did when she stood down. “She’s going to bring together all her former Cabinet ministers. She’ll plot and give them orders. “They threaten a guerilla war against Boris. She’s angry and will get even.” As she left No Mrs May said she hoped for a Brexit “that works for the whole United Kingdom” – a remark seen as a message to her successor. The replacement of her Cabinet with hardline Brexiteers has given Mrs May a taste for revenge, insiders say.  Within hours of the new PM taking over,  full Cabinet ministers and four others who attended Cabinet were sacked or resigned. The clear-out included many of her old guard. International trade ­secretary Liam Fox and Greg Clark, the business secretary, left their roles, as did ­education secretary Damian Hinds, and James Brokenshire, the housing and communities secretary. Sources say Mr Johnson’s strategy was a gamble – and he is relying on outgoing ministers staying loyal.  One insider said: “They’ve fired people who they think will vote for the Government’s deal on Brexit. That’s why you’ve seen strange people brought in – they had to be bought off. “There are loads of people Mrs May gave positions to. They owe her.” If, as expected, the Tories lose the Brecon and Radnorshire by-election on Thursday to the Liberal ­Democrats, the Government’s working majority will fall from two to one. It will be the smallest of any PM since John Major. The insider added: “Can you imagine getting anything through ” Mrs Thatcher fell out with Mr Major over his handling of the economy just weeks after she resigned as PM. They had a row in January  over interest rates and she was furious about his plan to abandon the poll tax. Brutal reshuffle strategist is real power at No Leave campaign architect Dominic Cummings is believed to have pulled the strings on Boris ­Johnson’s brutal cabinet cull. The reshuffle, dubbed the Night of the Blond Knives, was the bloodiest many in Westminster remember as the new PM dished senior posts out to hardline Brexiteers. From the outside, it looked like a shambles. But those in the know say it was a highly efficient operation and unelected official Mr Cummings is now the real power in Downing Street. Insiders say the reshuffle bore all the hallmarks of one of his favourite tactics – known as the “OODA Loop” and used by fighter pilots.

title: mums shock after nine year
story: NewsMums shock after nine-year-old daughters growing pains turn out to be cancerWhen Carol Pake’s daughter Katie complained of a sore knee, no one could predict what would follow…ShareCommentsByRosie Hopegood:,  JUL NewsKatie was so poorly she had to have part of her leg amputated"Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailKatie was nine when she felt a click in her knee, but mum Carol, , wasn’t too worried.After all, Katie was a seemingly fit and healthy little girl, so she assumed it was just growing pains, or a sprain that avid swimmer Katie had picked up at the pool. Nevertheless, Carol took Katie to the GP, who advised rest and pain relief.Her leg looked fine, apart from a slight graze on her shin.But when Katie’s knee continued to hurt, they went back and this time Katie was sent for an x-ray.    ‘The radiologist took a long time and took lots of dferent pictures, so I started to wonder what was wrong,’ remembers Carol.‘When they told us to make an urgent doctor’s appointment for the next day, we began to worry.’ Carol’s husband Grant, , went with Katie to the appointment the following day.The doctor told her to wait outside the room, and delivered devastating news – there was a dark shadow on Katie’s knee, and doctors believed it may be cancer. After that, things moved quickly.Katie saw a surgeon that very afternoon, and was booked in for a biopsy the following week.‘We decided not to tell Katie at this stage, as we didn’t want to worry her, so she was quite oblivious at first – she just wanted to know what was wrong with her knee,’ says Carol.‘But she was in a lot of pain by the time she had the biopsy and was struggling to walk without crutches.’ A week after the biopsy, the family were given the terrible news that Katie had osteosarcoma, a rare type of bone cancer.‘Telling my little girl she had cancer was the worst moment of my le,’ says Carol.‘Her first reaction was, “Just get it out.”‘Later we found out that she messaged one of her friends and said she thought she was going to die.’    Katie started chemotherapy.‘In the oncology ward, we saw patients walking around with no hair, and Katie worried about the same happening to her,’ says Carol. ‘Seeing how ill the other children looked – with feeding tubes and wires trailing from them – opened our eyes to what Katie was about to go through.‘We wondered how we were going to cope.’ Katie became ill very quickly.Her hair fell out in clumps, so she got her hair cut into a bob.Doctors came up with a treatment plan that involved Katie having a large part of her shin removed and replaced with a special metal bar that could be ened as she grew. It was a high-risk operation, but the family tried their hardest to remain positive for Katie.The day of the surgery came around, but just  minutes before Katie was due to go in, doctors halted the operation with grave new concerns. Punishing treatment A biopsy found that the cancer had spread to her thighs, hips and spine.‘They told us she only had a % chance of survival,’ says Carol. ‘It felt completely unreal.‘Doctors upped the chemo dose because we were fighting a losing battle – I told them to do whatever they needed to do to get Katie through this cancer. ‘It was really gruelling.‘Katie’s mouth and throat ulcers were so bad she could barely drink.‘I told herI could take all the pain away and switch places with her I would – she just said, “But you can’t, Mum.”’ Carol and Grant made the tough decision to keep the seriousness of the prognosis from their daughter, because they were worried it would be too much for her to cope with.But unbeknown to them, Katie had found out from a nurse just how ill she was – and heartbreakingly kept it a secret that she knew. The best gt Katie began a punishing new round of chemo that lasted several months. Just before Christmas, she had a full body scan to check on her progress.‘The oncologist came running in to see us and gave us incredible news – the cancer had retreated from her spine and hips!’ says Carol. ‘Although it was still present in her shin and thigh, this meant an operation was now possible. ‘To be told that she had a chance of survival just before Christmas was the best gt imaginable.’ The over-the-moon family had their best ever festive season together, knowing that Katie would be able to have a le-saving operation in the new year.  In February, just before her th birthday, Katie underwent an eight-hour rotationplasty operation to remove the cancer from her leg.Katie was the first patient to have the complex operation at the children’s hospital in Edinburgh.Surgeons amputated her leg from the mid-thigh, removed the cancerous middle-section, before reattaching her calf and foot, rotated at  degrees, so that her heel joint became a new knee.Doctors hoped this would allow Katie to continue her active lestyle much more than a traditional amputation. Amazing recovery ‘Coming round from the surgery, with so many cannulas and wires coming out of her arms was one of the toughest moments of Katie’s le,’ says Carol. ‘She didn’t have any feeling in her leg because there were nerves attached to the cancerous bone, so she had to take medication for the nerve damage and completely retrain her brain.’ But  months on, Katie is thriving.She has regular check ups and x-rays to make sure everything is healthy, but so far she’s been getting better by the day.In August, she’ll be starting secondary school, but still plans to find the time to keep up her sports, as well as volunteering for cancer charities such as Cancer Research UK. After plenty of physio, she can now walk on her prosthetic using a crutch and is even more active than ever. In fact, she’s such a good swimmer that she’s been picked for an elite squad of paraswimmers and has won gold at the Junior and Senior Scottish Disability Sport National Swimming Championships.She’s also recently started to play football and do wheelchair racing, and has been approached by the Scottish Triathlon squad. ‘She has a determination that is beyond her years,’ says Carol.‘We are proud to be her mum and dad – she’s such a resilient young child.‘When she grows up she wants to be a surgeon like the ones who saved her le.‘If not, then a Paralympian!’ ■

story: NewsDozens of couples conned out of hundreds of pounds by missing wedding plannerOne bride said she felt taken advantage of after she employed the wedding planner to help bring her special day forward when her mum was diagnosed with terminal cancerShareCommentsByAlex Grove:,  JUL Updated:,  JUL NewsSam and fiancé Phil brought their wedding forward after learning that her mum had incurable cancer "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email Dozens of angry couples have had their nuptials left in tatters after allegedly being scammed out of hundreds of pounds by a wedding planner.Bride Sam Devine, who brought her wedding forward so that her terminally ill mum could see her marry her fiancé Phil Leach, is one of those who claims she has been conned. She came across one wedding planner allegedly offering bargains which she initially thought were “too good to be true”.    After getting in touch, messaging her and meeting the woman face to face, Sam was convinced everything was “kosher”. She says she paid more than £ to cover the cost of decorations and £ to cover the deposit for the hire of a marquee. Sam says she last spoke to her on July  before going on Facebook on Friday to find posts and comments from people who said they had been scammed. She claims she attempted to contact the woman again having heard the news but has since heard nothing and she fears she may now have lost hundreds of pounds. “I felt upset, shocked and just absolutely gutted,” Sam said. “I just couldn’t believe somebody could prey on someone’s weakness like that. “Your wedding day is supposed to be the best day of your le and I knew that mine was going to be bittersweet because although I am marrying Phil we had to bring it forward so my mum could be there. “I feel taken advantage of and I did have doubts at first and everybody said it was too good to be true but the messages from her reassured me. I hope the police find her and justice is served because she could have done this to hundreds of people and I just hope people get their money back. Kayleigh Enderby is getting married to her partner Marc Hodge in just four weeks’ time. She was convinced by a friend to go with the alleged fraudster and was encouraged to hand over £ after seeing positive reviews on her Facebook page. This covered the cost of cars, a buffet and room decorations, and Kayleigh thought everything was in hand until she looked on Facebook on Friday and realised she had been the victim of an alleged scam. “My head just went,” said the -year-old mum from north Hull. “She gave me a package for a certain amount and everything was arranged and paid for but I kept in contact and last spoke to her on July . “Then I went on Facebook yesterday and was like ‘wow – what are we going to do  We get married in four weeksapos.”  Fortunately, Kayleigh has since been reimbursed through her bank and has even tried to help out other desperate brides affected by the alleged scandal. I’m complaining about it being just four weeks away but there are brides getting married today and it’s just lucky everyone is pulling together.” Kaylie Norrie claims she knows the wedding planner as an “old family friend” and after her services were recommended she saw no reason as to why she should doubt her legitimacy. And now weaposre joining in. Sam Brook works at Sainsburyaposs in Bath and realised the scheme - which supports local communities through a wide range of initiatives put forward by each store - could help make shopping a far more straightforward experience for the  million deaf or hard of hearing people in the UK. That is why Sainsburyaposs colleagues turned their Bath store into a aposSignsburyapossapos for four days earlier this month.  With the new spelling applied to the sign above the door,  colleagues from the Bath Sainsburyaposs learned how to sign several common words and phrases when interacting with customers. That meant they were able to greet anyone at the door, askthey have a Nectar Card or even discuss the weather. This video explains the whole campaign:  We were so impressed by the idea, we decided to join up with the initiative and learn some sign language ourselves. In the video at the top of the page, you can see Daily Mirror columnist Eva Simpson getting a beginneraposs guide to signing from Sainsburyaposs Jonty Parry, finding out how to sign five key phrases that should allow anyone to communicate more easily with someone deaf. The speed with which Eva was able to pick up the phrases shows how easy it is to learn just a few useful bits of sign language - and how valuable that could be when it comes to having a chat with someone who is hard of hearing. About , deaf people in the UK use British Sign Language. British Sign Language isnapost a simple duplication of spoken English. It has its own syntax and grammar, and the order is dferent.  E.g. In English, you would say ‘What is your name ’ In BSL, you would say ‘Your name what ’There isnapost a universal sign language.  There are over  recorded sign languages.For example, American Sign Language is not the same as British Sign Language.  ASL alphabet is one handed, and BSL is two handed. In fact, there are so many dferent versions of sign language across the globe, you can here see how Happy Christmas is signed in  dferent countries!   Paul Robertson, the store manager at Bath, explained that was the exact idea behind aposSignsburyapossapos. “I thought it was the perfect time to use the opportunity to explore new ways to make our store more deaf-friendly, he said. We have many hard of hearing customers in Bath and always want to make their experience as brilliant as possible, and we hope Signsbury’s will help better their time in store even more.  The in-store drive to make the hearing-impaired feel more included is just one example of many initiatives being rolled out as part of the  Days of Community scheme. All , Sainsburyaposs colleagues are being given the chance to volunteer for a cause they feel passionately about in their local community. From community fundraising to hosting events and launching their own local campaigns, they are supporting causes ranging from community gardens to sports teams and elderly care homes. When in conversation with anyone deaf or hard of hearing, there are some very simple things you can do to make things a little easier…Relax Don’t panic!
