title: prestonpans-schools-pupils-aiming-get-involved-community
story: St Gabrielrsquos RC Primary School sent P representatives Olivia Lees, Ciaran Kelly, Fraser Graham, and Daniel McCabe, all , to speak to Prestonpans Community Council about their work and the potential involvement of much younger participants.The school was recently successful in achieving its UNICEF Rights Respecting School gold award, which means that it had proved that it incorporates the United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child into the school through both teaching and actions.It now aims to take this further and bring this ethos into the surrounding community.The children were given the chance of addressing the meeting, which included ward councillors Fiona OrsquoDonnell and Neil Gilbert, to ask questions and discuss the best ways to engage young people with what is going on in the community and to ensure their input is noted.The children asked about the plans for the site of the former Cockenzie Power Station and whether more activities for young people such as Rainbows and Scouts could be introduced to the areaWhen addressing the councillors and community councillors, Daniel, a house captain from St Gabrielrsquos, said: ldquoItrsquos important for us at this stage to know what our future is going to hold, and to try and make a dference when and where we can.ldquoTo be involved in the community council in some way would be fantastic, as it would give us comfort to know that the community is being taken care of, as well as what decisions were being made that might affect us.It was decided that the community council would send the agenda for each meeting to the school a few days before the meeting took place so that the children could see it and comment on any issues being raised.The community council said in a statement: ldquoWe would like to thank the four fantastic pupils from St Gabrielrsquos Primary School who attended the community council.ldquoIt was so refreshing to have such polite and knowledgeable young people along to one of our meetings to share their opinions and views on our agenda topics and ask the questions they feel most relevant to their lives.ldquoWe look forward to welcoming them along to future meetings and collaborating with them on the issues that affect all of us living in Prestonpans.

title: fringe-sea-q-amp-professor-ben-garrod
story: The professor is a broadcaster, author and evolutionary biologist at the University of East Anglia and has done a QA to gear people up for his show.Were you interested in dinosaurs as a child Not just dinosaurs, but anything prehistoric. My first fossil find was on a beach near where I grew up. I was five years old and was on a day out with mum and dad. We wound the fossilised shell of a belemnite, which was a relative of the squid we see alive today. It was over  million years old and that blew my socks off! It made me start questioning where all these ancient animals went, why we donrsquot have dinosaurs around now and how the planet could be so old. Obviously, I loved dinosaurs too and loved reading about them in all my old books, imagining what it would be like to see a T. rex walking through my garden.Why are so many children obsessed with them So many people are obsessed with dinosaurs, both kids and adults alike. Itrsquos hard to pin down exactly why we love them so much and I think itrsquos for a few dferent reasons. First of all, when we are growing up we love to learn lots of facts about things . . . the speed of fast cars maybe or the size of planets in space. Dinosaurs are the same and we love to learn how fast an Allosaurus could run or discover which was the biggest. I also think they inspire us through being so big, fierce and scary but we feel safe because we know dinosaurs can never hurt us because theyrsquore all extinct You are described as an lsquoevolutionary biologistrsquo ndash what exactly does that entail Irsquom a Professor of Evolutionary Biology at the University of East Anglia. Sounds fancy doesnrsquot it but itrsquos the coolest job in the world. The lsquoBiologyrsquo bit just means I get to study all sorts of le ndash it could be anything that is alive or was ever alive, so anything from a chimpanzee or a Troodon, to a butterfly or monkey puzzle tree. The lsquoEvolutionrsquo bit means I study how these living organisms change and adapt over time. How does a changing marine environment affect sharks or how does predation from birds affect camouflage in lizards  All these changes are down to evolution. I study le and how it changes, and I share that knowledge with as many people as possible. Being a scientist means you get to study cool stuff like this every single day.How many books have you written I have written six books so far. My series lsquoSo You Think You Know About Dinosaursrsquo are pretty cool, evenI do say so myself. I wanted them to be the most up to date dinosaur books in  million years and although I wanted them to be enjoyed by young readers, the content should be the same as that which I teach to university students. I know young readers really want to learn and we donrsquot need to dumb stuff down, but with a few more cartoons, quizzes and examples, I think they can be enjoyed by young and older readers. Each book focuses on just one species and it was so hard to pick just six. Eventually, I chose Tyrannosaurus, Triceratops, Stegosaurus, Diplodocus, Velociraptor and Spinosaurus. Therersquos something there for everyone and between them, these dinosaurs really tell the complete story.Herersquos something we all want to know ndash which dinosaur would have been the most dangerous to humans Arrrrrgh, this is such a tough question. Is one T. rex worse than one hundred velociraptors  Even something like a Triceratops could have been deadly. Itrsquos easier to say which dinosaurs would have been safe . . . there wouldnrsquot have been many. Stegosaurus had tail spikes around one metre long, Ankylosaurus had a tail club which could have destroyed a car and Argentinosaurus weighed so much that yoursquod definitely want to be stepped on. And theyrsquore just the herbivores! Imagine what the meat-eaters would have done.And which was the very biggest Ah, this is a question I get asked a lot. There has been huge debate and even some arguments between scientists. Irsquom not going to give it away ndash yoursquoll have to come to my show and find out. Irsquoll give you a clue . . . itrsquos not the one you think it is.What dinosaurs would have roamed around this country many millions of years ago This is a really hard one to answer for each show right now. We had so many prehistoric species that wersquore spoilt for choice now. We had giant sauropods up on the Western Isles in Scotland, early relatives of T. rex in Wales and even the fish-eating Baryonyx on the Isle of Wight. There are also discoveries of marine reptiles such as the dolphin-like ichthyosaurs and super-predator pliosaurs all around our coastlines all the time. The best thing to do is get out there and go have a look or visit your local museum and discover what used to swim, fly, run and plod around near where you live, millions of years ago.Were numbers declining before whatever environmental catastrophe wiped them out about m years ago and would they have become extinct naturally No, they werenrsquot. The Cretaceous period was the third major period of the dinosaurs and they were doing really well. Some of the most well-known dinosaurs were around right about the time when the asteroid struck. It was also the age of the titanosaurs ndash the biggest dinosaurs to ever live. If that asteroid hadnrsquot crashed into the sea just north of Mexico then in all likelihood, things might have been very dferent and you might really have had a Tyrannosaursus in your garden or a Protoceratops in your playground. But remember, the asteroid did not kill all the dinosaurs . . .Have you ever been on expeditions to find dinosaur remains and where are the places most likely to find them I have. My favourite was when I went with Sir David Attenborough to Argentina to film the discovery and excavation of a true dino giant. The great thing about loving dinosaurs and living in the British Isles is that we have so many fossils of dinosaurs and other prehistoric species. There are certain beaches and riversides famous for fossils and you have a very good chance of finding the fossil bones of a prehistoric marine reptile or shark teeth or ammonite shells. You always have to go with an adult and thoroughly plan your trip because fossil hunting can be dangerous but itrsquos so much fun.Do you identy at all with lsquodinosaur expertrsquo characters on film or television There have been some well-known characters on TV who study dinosaurs but usually theyrsquore rubbish. Look at Ross from Friends . . . Irsquom pretty sure he couldnrsquot tell the dference between the head and butt of a Dreadnoughtus. Characters like that donrsquot inspire me. Real scientists are much better and inspire me every day. The men and women who spend their lives digging up fossils and investigating how these animals and plants lived are much cooler than a TV character.

title: music-fan-kevin-proves-39-s-popmaster
story: Kevin OrsquoDonnell stole the show when he appeared on PopMaster on BBC Radio .A score of  out of  was enough to win the quiz on Ken Brucersquos show.Kevin, who runs his own joinery and garden business, told the Courier: ldquoIt was something that I always wanted to do.ldquoI am right into my music and PopMaster is probably the premier music quiz in Britain.The -year-oldrsquos opponent managed a score of , with Kevin declared the winner and receiving the prize of a digital speaker in the shape of an old-style microphone.The prize has taken pride of place in Kevinrsquos West Barns home, with dozens of people getting in touch with him to offer their congratulations since the show was broadcast.He said: ldquoI met Bruce Springsteen in  in Newcastle and I think this is not quite up there with that but it is not far off.The popular radio quiz has been running for a number of years and each contestant is asked  questions based on popular music from the s through to the present day.He said: ldquoI have listened to Ken Bruce for a good  or  years and the last couple of years I have tried to get on the show.ldquoMy kids have always been saying to me to go.ldquoMy son, Conor, is the lead guitarist in The Tesla Coils and we are always discussing and talking about music.The music fan, who spoke to the Courier as he was en route to see American rock legends Kiss perform at the SSE Hydro in Glasgow, played down his achievement and said the questions simply fell in his favour.ldquoYou can get a possible  points thatrsquos the maximum you can score, said Kevin. ldquoThat is based on  questions and it is just general music knowledge. It just depends onit is for you.ldquoAll my stuff is s and s music andthe questions had been about the year  I would have got five out of !ldquoIt is really luck andthe questions are for you ndash it just happened that the questions were from my era.

title: connor-farrell-barber-stars-scottish-open-golf-renaissance-club
story: Bernd Wiesberger, who won the tournament at The Renaissance Club earlier this month, was among the professionals putting their feet up for a moment and getting a trim from Connor Farrell.The barber, who lives in Pencaitland, cut the hair of more than  golfers, caddies, management teams and sponsors.He said: ldquoYou see all these players on the television and then you get to have a good chat with them face to face. It was a good experience.ldquoWe were there and set up on the Monday and were Tuesday through Thursday, Friday cutting hair.ldquoWe were only supposed to be there on Tuesday and Wednesday but we got asked to stay on.ldquoWe reckon we did anywhere between  and  haircuts and it was all just complimentary. We did Bernd Wiesberger, who won the tournament, and Matt Wallace, who is ranked rd in the world.ldquoThey were all good guys. They are just normal people at the end of the day.ldquoWe talked about ious things ndash they wanted to know about good places to go eat in Edinburgh, ious local spots and seemed to like East Lothian and Edinburgh in general.Other golfers stepping into the hot seat included Lee Slattery, who finished tied for ninth at the competition, and West Lothianrsquos Stephen Gallacher.Former Ross High School pupil Connor, who is the owner and barber at Chaps Barber in Newcraighall, revealed that although the haircuts were complimentary, the golfers did offer generous tips and said: ldquoThey were pretty good ndash I cannot complain.Connor, who has been a barber for the last  months, got the chance through a family connection.His older sister Christy, , is dating North Berwick golfer Grant Forrest, who finished tied for rd at the event.Connor, , who plays golf at Longniddry Golf Club, was able to cheer Grant on.He said: ldquoThe European Tour got involved with Grantrsquos management company Bounce Sports.ldquoFrom there, they got the ball in motion and all the logistics of it.ldquoThese things take massive planning to get things done and it was quite a y process.ldquoIt took about two or three months to get it all finalised.

title: plea-save-former-dolphin-hotel-s-late
story: New le could be breathed into the former Dolphin Hotel, which included a bar and lounge on the ground floor.The bar closed in February  but the upstairs, which was used as a hotel, has not been in use for nearly  years.Developer The Dolphin InnLtd wants to ensure the building, on Dunbarrsquos Queenrsquos Road, has a future.Plans have been lodged with East Lothian Council for a hostel, complete with reception and cafe, on the ground floor.Under the proposals, the first floor would have four bedrooms, with three shower rooms and a family suite. The second floor would feature six bedrooms, with four bath or shower rooms, and the top floor acting as a managerrsquos flat.The developer has highlighted the poor state of the building and said that the first and second floors were ldquoseriously affected by dry rot and are unsafe.A ldquopriority of repairing the building and eradicating the advancing dry rot has been identied, with the developer keen to bring the building back into use ldquobefore itrsquos too late.Pippa Swan, chairwoman of the townrsquos community council, told the Courier she had previously seen inside the building and it was ldquoin a terrible state of repair.She said: ldquoAnybody that wants to come in and invest high-quality renovation in Dunbar is to be welcomed.ldquoIt is wonderful that the building, which is so prominent, is in line for a facelt.ldquoMy understanding is that the client group is going to be aimed at walkers and surfers and, again, that would be warmly welcomed.Attempts had previously been made to see the building re-open as a hotel. However, there was ldquono interest from potential developers.A design and access statement, which is included within the planning application, notes: ldquoItrsquos quite possible there has been no demand for this property to be retained as a hotel due to competition in the immediate vicinity, namely The Royal Mackintosh Hotel on Station Road and the Hillside Hotel on Queenrsquos Road.Two years ago, Dunbar Trout Farm Ltd, was given permission to transform the building. Those plans, approved in August , included the creation of two shops and four flats.However, the design and access statement reads: ldquoSince this permission was obtained, despite evidence of marketing, there has been insufficient interest for its use as shops and flats.ldquoOur clientsrsquo proposal is to redevelop the building for use as a hostel, providing accommodation to visitors to Dunbar, [primarily] those who would take part in the large number of outdoor activities available within the area.ldquoA small flat-roofed single-storey extension to the side is proposed to provide associated laundry room.

title: charlotte-cowan-takes-west-highland-way-memory-dad-kenny
story: Charlotte Cowan, from North Berwick is completing the walk, over five days, beginning on September .The -year-old is raising money for the townrsquos Edington Cottage Hospital, the place where her dad spent his last week.Charlottersquos dad Kenny Cowan was a support worker but a joiner by trade.Having lost her mother when she was a baby, Kenny raised Charlotte and her brother as a single parent with help from her gran and other family members.Charlotte, who lives on Lochbridge Road, had a great relationship with her dad.ldquoI was very close to him and practically attached to his hip when I was little, I would go everywhere with him, she told the Courier.ldquoHe was such a genuinely lovely guy, no one had a bad word to say about him.ldquoHe was a big personality in the community and was so well known and loved by many.Kenny played bowls for Dirleton Bowling Club, darts in North Berwick and was an honorary member at the townrsquos rugby club for  years.He had been suffering with a bad back on and off for years, thinking it was sciatica.But in October last year the pain was getting worse, to the point he struggled to get out of bed.Two months later, Kenny was told he had stage four aggressive cancer in his spine which had spread and nothing more could be done.It was his last wish to be able to go to Edington Cottage Hospital before he died.ldquoUp until his very last day he had lots of visitors in to see him, Charlotte said.ldquoI donrsquot think [the Edington] had ever known as many visitors.ldquoHe was laughing and joking and listening to his beloved Runrig.Kenny died on January , aged .Charlotte said: ldquoIt was extremely hard to lose him. It was one of the hardest things to go through but we take comfort in the fact he said he would always be watching over us and we had time at the end to get to say goodbye to him and he knew how loved he was.She has always wanted to walk the West Highland Way, being a lover of the outdoors and a keen hiker.ldquoFamily and work commitments always seemed to get in the way or I just thought it would be too expensive, she said.ldquoWhen my dad passed away, I wanted to do something for him it kind of gave me the push to stop putting it off and actually go for it.ldquoI just want to do something big in his honour.ldquoI would just like to raise a bit of money for the hospital as it is a huge part of our community.ldquoI went there with my children when they were young, my gran and nana spent time in there, and my dadrsquos dad spent his last days in there also.ldquoMy dad was so well looked after that I just wanted to give something back, say thank you for looking after my dad and the community so well.In terms of the walk she is excited about the challenge ahead, saying: ldquoI canrsquot wait for the walk, I know itrsquos going to be hard doing it over five days, which is an average of  miles a day. I just hope my feet are up to the challenge!Charlottersquos training is going well, having already completed practice walks on her route to check out the terrain.She has also walked up Ben Nevis and completed the Three Lochs Way in one day.ldquoI havenrsquot managed any consecutive days walks yet as with kids and work itrsquos not easy to fit in, she said. ldquoBut when schools go back in August, I will have a month to get last bits of training in. I do feel ready, though, definitely.ldquoA bad blister could ruin it all or an injury, but hopefully neither will happen. Irsquove just got to be as prepared as possible and keep my fingers crossed for the rest.Charlotte is not doing the challenge solo, with three walking friends going along with her.She said: ldquoSupport has been great, everyone is getting behind me and wishing me well and helping with sponsors. I really appreciate any money raised.She said a special thank you to her step-mum Heather, who met Kenny when Charlotte was  and later married him, saying: ldquoShe has been a huge support for me through everything and I really want to thank her for that.On her goals, she said: ldquoJust being able to give something back is all Irsquod like to achieve.ldquoWe will be celebrating with a big gin at the end! The feeling of achievement and knowing I will have done my dad proud will be the best feeling, though. He would probably have called me crazy for doing this as he did for a few things I had done, but I know hersquod be proud and thatrsquos all I want to do.Donate at uk.virginmoneygiving CharlotteCowan or via the sponsor sheet at Charlottersquos work, Smithrsquos Pharmacy, North Berwick High Street.

title: dog-walker-stalker-sentenced-next-year
story: David Page followed and filmed the woman for over five years after he spotted her Labradoodle allegedly becoming overly-friendly with his greyhound-cross while out on a walk with his pet.Page, , used a GoPro camera, a mobile phone and a long-lens camera to intimidate the woman and her family when they took their dog out for walks in the town.The woman was forced to call the police and, after denying the allegations, Page, of Castle Street, eventually stood trial at Edinburgh Sherf Court last year.He was found guilty of causing fear and alarm to the woman and her family between January  and October  following the trial last July.He was also found guilty of a separate charge of using abusive language towards employees at East Lothian Council during a phone call on October , .Sherf Alistair Noble issued Page with a four-year non-harassment order banning him from approaching the woman and deferred full sentence to last week.However, when Page appeared in court, the sherf again deferred sentence on him to January next year.

story: Hugh Panton literally went head over heels to help Friends of the Earth Scotland as he backflipped for a mile along Belhaven Bay.The -year-old, who lives just a mile from the beach, on Dunbarrsquos Bayswell Road, told the Courier: ldquoI was graduating from the University of Aberdeen and wanted to do something a bit special.ldquoI have always wanted to do a fundraiser event but never really had the time when I was at university.ldquoI decided I would do something that capitalises on my skills as a flipping enthusiast and had a couple of ideas.ldquoI thought maybe I would try to do , flips in five days or something and then it just came to me to try to do a mile of flips.ldquoAt the time, it sounded quite ridiculous but I really wanted to try it.The former Dunbar Grammar School pupil spent three days last month working his way from west to east along the picturesque beach for the challenge, which took him about  hours to complete.Hugh, who has started work as an assistant countryside ranger at the Loch of the Lowes Nature Reserve, near Dunkeld, was not the only one on the beach, as he attracted curious glances from onlookers.Hugh, who studied geography at university, managed to raise more than pound, and said: ldquoI would go down to the bay and I go to the very far end where there are not too many people.ldquoAfter a wee while training before doing the event, people would be walking by and their heads just slowly started following me down the beach.ldquoThere were horse riders as well and the horses did not like it at all and I would have to wait for them to pass.The flips were broken down into blocks of five or  so Hugh could keep his bearings, with the talented tumbler completing about  flips over each of the three days ndash  in total.Kerrigan Bell, development manager for Friends of the Earth Scotland, said: ldquoWersquore delighted that Hugh decided to raise much-needed funds.

title: airshow-lifeboat-fete-gullane-games-musselburgh-festival-spott-fete
story: The Courier has put together a list of five of the top things to do over Saturday and Sunday.Whether it is planes, boats, horses or much more, there is plenty to keep everyone occupied - eventhe weather isnt perfect.. title: records-tumble-mercury-rises-scotland-s-hottest-ever-july-day
story: Yesterday saw the hottest day of the year so far across Scotland, while Edinburgh experienced its warmest day since records began as the height of the summer heatwave arrived in force.But while some sweltered in offices, shops and factories, for those who could it was the chance to get out and enjoy balmy climes more often seen on the Mediterranean coast.Many swarmed to Portobello beach to take advantage of a cooling dip, while in Glasgow parks and shady green spaces became magnets for sunseekers and families enjoying the sun.:Climate crisis lsquoraises riskrsquo of more intense heatwavesA temperature of Cwas recorded in the capital in the afternoon, breaking a record which had stoodsince .This was the highest temperature ever recorded in Scotland in July ndash while in England, London and Essex baked in .C.Met Office Forecasters said the new July record outstripped the previous high for the month of .Cset at Heathrow in July .It makes Thursday the second hottest UK day ever, beating the .C recorded in August .However, the sweltering temperatures could spark thundery downpours, with a yellow warning for thunderstorms issued for most of England except the south-west, and parts of Scotland from pm on Thursday until am on Friday. The storms could lead to flash flooding, disruption of train and busservices and even power cuts.Experts at the Met Office say the current weather pattern is driving hot air from the south, and some areas experienced a ldquotropical night on Wednesday night, with the temperatures staying above C in spots such as St Jamesrsquos Park, central London, Wattisham, in Suffolk, and Cromer, in Norfolk."@context": "https:schema.org","@type": "VideoObject","name": "Edinburgh residents enjoy Britains hottest July day","description": "Edinburgh residents enjoy Britains hottest July day","thumbnailUrl": "https:cdn.jwplayer thumbs rzeyKbr-.jpg","uploadDate": "--T::+:","duration": "PDTHMS","contentUrl": "https:cdn.jwplayer manests rzeyKbr.mu","embedUrl": "https:www.heraldscotland video  ","publisher": "@type": "Organization","name": "HeraldScotland","logo": "@type": "ImageObject","url": "https:www.heraldscotland sitelogo ","width": ,"height": The Met Office said high pressure over eastern Europe and Scandinavia, combined with the position of the jet stream, was funnelling hot air from Europe which had originated in North Africa.People are being urged to take precautions against the heat, including staying hydrated, staying inside at the hottest time of the day, avoiding exercise and wearing loose, light clothing.Medical experts are warning that few lessons have been learned from last yearrsquos heatwave, and few hospitals are prepared for the impact of intense heat.Nick Scriven, president of the Society for Acute Medicine, said NHS workers were ldquostruggling, with ldquooverheated and exhausted staff at greater risk of making errors. ldquoLast year, hospitals hired in large fans and coolers for a week or so but have got nothing long-term in place ndash they are purely reactive not proactive, he said, adding that there was often little in place for staff to get fluids onwards.CLIMATE FOR CHANGE: All of the latest stories on the environmentMeanwhile, doctors are advising people in Glasgow to remember to take care in the sun, particularly the very young, the very old and those with chronic diseases. A spokesman said it is not just sunburn, dehydration and hayfever which people need to be mindful of, but also respiratory problems, particularly the elderly.Dr Emilia Crighton, NHS Greater Glasgow and Clydersquos deputy director of public health, said: ldquoA number of Scottish people are fair-skinned and need to take adequate steps to ensure their skin is protected. As the weather forecast is for sunshine over the next few days everyone should take a few simple precautions.ldquoChildren are especially vulnerable and care should be taken to ensure they are covered up adequately. Babies, in particular, need to be covered up. With both sun-creams and sun protection clothing designed for babies and children there is no need for children to be over-exposed to the sun.Charity Age Scotland, which campaigns on behalf of the elderly, urged people to look out for their older relatives and neighbours, who are particularly vulnerable to high temperatures.Michelle Supple, director of charity services, said: ldquoWe would encourage everyone to check on older neighbours, friends and family to make sure they are doing well and seethey need anything. Something as simple as helping open a window or popping to the shops to pick up some sunscreen can make a huge dference to someonersquos comfort and wellbeing.A Scottish Government spokesman said: ldquoWe would of course advise sensible precaution in all extreme weather conditions, and recommend people monitor and act on any weather warnings from the Met Office.

title: trans-rights-questions-yaniv-male-genitals-waxing-case-must-answered-scotland
story: Concerns frequently pooh-poohed as misleading nonsense, the sort of scaremongering that never happens in real le. Unfortunately - for all concerned - fears have been realised.A trans woman, Jessica Yaniv, approached a number of female beauticians to ask for a Brazilian bikini wax, all - perhaps by coincidence - were lone home workers, the majority of whom were immigrant women.Unfortunately, Ms Yaniv was unable to find any beautician willing to carry out the intimate wax because she still retains male genitalia and each of these women only worked on female genitalia.:Are you trans  Next Scottish census to ask questions on gender IDMs Yaniv, a trans rights campaigner, then raised action against  of the women at British Columbiarsquos human rights tribunal, alleging discrimination and seeking damages of several thousanddollars from each.It was too much for several of the women to fight and so they folded their businesses instead, losing their livelihoods.The case cleaves opinion in two: either it is discriminatory of the beauticians to refuse to wax a trans womans genitals regardless of what they look like, or it is discriminatory to force a woman to handle male genitals against her will.The tribunal will make a decision - and that decision may well be to disregard womens boundaries and dignity by finding for Ms Yaniv and asserting that the law believes it is discrimination for women to refuse to touch a penis when that penis belongs to a trans woman.Ms Yaniv has posted deeply troubling comments on social media about young girls, although she claimed at the tribunal her account was hacked. There are those who would say she is vexatious and should be disregarded. Fiona Robertson, the SNPs National Womens and Equalities Convener, says Ms Yaniv is a female predator and that women predators often use their womanliness to gain access to victims.Critics of Ms Robertsons stance would strongly dispute male predatory behaviour being attributed to women.I would not dream of speaking for trans people but Im going to take a stab that the vast majority just want to get on with their lives peaceably and,asked about the Yaniv case, would be of the "not in my name" persuasion. Trans people cannot want this sort of legal action either, yet activists and allies have remained silent on the case.However, it cant be ignored and certainly not by a Scotland where there is a bitter ide between trans allies and, for want of a better shorthand, womens allies.Trans woman are women has become a political slogan in support of self ID and of respecting the rights of trans people but to take it to its conclusion is to fundamentally redefine the word "woman" and remove the element of sex from the words definition.The argument from some feminists is that the introduction of self ID is the beginning of a creep towards removing womens sex-based rights.Currently "sex" is a protected characteristic and so, for example, womens refuges have the right to refuse to house male-bodied people or, indeed, employ male-bodied people.Jo Swinson, the new leader of the Liberal Democrats, has been highly vocal in declaring that trans women are women but less clear in defining exactly what she means. If it is the Liberal Democrats stance that trans women are literally women then it suggests the Liberal Democrats would support the removal of the sex-based exemption.To avoid Yaniv-style legal cases, the Scottish Government must be explicit in how the Equality Act will apply to any new law.But explicit answers to troubling questions are exactly what this public conversation is lacking and no wonder when you have an MP, Mhairi Black, calling women who disagree with self ID "Jeremy Hunts", a rhyming slang it takes no genius to work out.The Scottish Government already confuses "sex" with "gender" in its consultation on self ID. Pro-self ID campaigners have pointed to the reassurance that there will be the protection of up to two years prison term for those who abuse self ID. Butyou cannot define "woman", how can you legislate effectively to determine who is or isnt really living as a woman : years of Stonewall: The fight for LGBT rightsIn Canada too, a woman has reported to the human rights tribunal that a womans shelter for recovering addicts made her homeless because she refused to share a twin room with a trans woman. The woman was a rape victim and felt frightened at being in close quarters with a male-bodied person who was "masc presenting", that is, maintained a beard and wore typically masculine clothes.There was no suitable alternative space in the refuge and so the woman was asked to leave. This is another scenario women have raised questions about but been given no clear answers.Scottish Womens Aid and Rape Crisis have both made statements saying they are in support of self ID. Rape Crisis also supports men so its no surprise the charity supports trans people - it would be an odd developmentthey did not.Scottish Womens Aid, the umbrella organisation for womens aid groups in Scotland, focuses on policy and research, it does not run refuges and so, while it supports self ID and takes a clear line that domestic abuse affects trans women too, its position is largely academic in that it will not have to deal with the frontline practicalities of balancing rights.Inidual womens aid charities in Scotland have gone on public record to say they have real concerns about self-ID.Wouldnt it be useful, instead of sloganeering and calling women c****, for politicians and charities to give explicit, detailed answers to questions being asked  The only way to allay fears is to tackle them head-on.Women are told their boundaries are not under threat - the Yaniv case contradicts this. They are told there is no conflict when it comes to women-only spaces such as refuges, they are told men will not pose as trans women to gain access to womens spaces - there are multiple cases in Canada of this happening.It will only help the debate to progressquestions raised in Canada are answered in Scotland - for the benefit of everyone.

title: english-mp-appointed-scotland-office-minister
story: The Prime Minister passed over  Scottish Conservative MPs to give the role to Robin Walker, the MP for Worcester, who will also double as a Northern Ireland minister.A huge honour to be made Minister for the union working with @BorisJohnson @ScotSecofState  @NIOgov - our precious union deserves to thrive through brexit  beyond. I will work with colleagues all across the UK to ensure that it doesThose apparently snubbed by Mr Johnson include his Tory leadership campaign manager in Scotland, Ross Thomson, the MP for Aberdeen South.A Downing Street source said Mr Walker would be an additional appointment at the Scotland Office, strengthening the governments commitment to the Union.Mr Johnson is expected to appoint a second junior Scotland Office minister this weekend, with Angus MP Kirstene Hair tipped for the job.The SNP said the decision was ldquoextraordinary and further humiliationfor Ms Davidson.It comes just two days after Mr Johnson ignored the Scottish Conservative leaderrsquos appeals to keep David Mundell as Scottish Secretary.The PMappointed Dumfries  Galloway MP Alister Jack to the role instead.:New Scottish Secretary: Im a hunting, shooting, fishing toffMr Walker, , the Oxford-educated son of the Tory peer Lord Peter Walker, was previously a junior Brexit minister.His father was also previously the MP for Worcester.Mr Walker effectively replaces Lord Ian Duncan, who had been the junior Scotland Office minister to Mr Mundell and a Northern Ireland minister, and has now been made a junior business and Northern Ireland minister.SNP MP Pete Wishart said: ldquoThe fact that all the Scottish MPs have apparently been passed over in this reshuffle tells you everything about Boris Johnsonrsquos assessment of them.ldquoItrsquos a slap in the face for Ruth Davidson ahead of her meeting with the Prime Minister next week.:SNP say Ruth Davidson lsquohumiliatedrsquo after David Mundell sacked against her adviceA Whitehall source said the important thing about Mr Walker was not his constituency, but that he was ldquovery good.Mr Walker held the nations brief in the Department for Exiting the European Union and has appeared before a number of Holyrood committeesand taken part the Joint Ministerial Committee on Europe with SNP ministers.

title: thousands-march-campbeltown-support-scottish-independence

title: independent-mp-jared-omara-resign
story: Mr OrsquoMara, MP for Sheffield Hallam, announced earlier this week that he would be taking time out from his duties to deal with his ldquomental health and personal issues regarding self-medication.The announcement came after Gareth Arnold, his chief of staff, resigned in a series of tweets published on Mr OrsquoMararsquos Twitter account.On Saturday, Mr Arnold said Mr OrsquoMara had asked him to stay on until a new MP takes the Sheffield Hallam seat.Here is my statement, I will be making a further statement in a few weeks. https:t.co HiPxUvcwmdash Jared OMaraJuly , Mr Arnold said: ldquoFrom September , hersquoll be resigning, triggering a by-election.He added: ldquoHersquos going, there will be a by-election and a new MP before the end of the year.Mr OrsquoMara sensationally took the Sheffield Hallam seat for Labour from former deputy prime minister Sir Nick Clegg in .:Jared OMaras spindoctor bows out with words of angerA by-election would be looked on with relish by the Liberal Democrats as they ride a resurgent wave after a strong showing in the European Parliament elections.Mr OrsquoMara had the whip withdrawn after apparently sexist and homophobic comments emerged, which he had posted on social media years earlier, but was readmitted to the party after receiving a formal warning.But last year, Mr OrsquoMara resigned from Labour, saying he had been ldquomade unfairly to feel like a criminal, and now sits as an independent.His announcement that he will resign as MP comes after allegations that he sexually harassed a former employee.But Mr Arnold said he had already made the decision to resign.He said: ldquoEven before this came out, hersquod already come to that decision when I spoke to him.ldquoI think it was an influencing factor but I think hersquod already made up his mind.In his statement on Thursday, Mr OrsquoMara said: ldquoI will be taking time out to receive professional help to deal with my mental health and personal issues regarding self-medication.He said: ldquoI would like to start by apologising to my family, my friends and my constituents. I have not been honest with you about the depths of my depression and self-loathing.ldquoWhen I started this job in  I was a dferent man: a confident and passionate man that wanted to help others.ldquoSadly, I was unable to do that because very quickly I was bullied and mistreated in a harsh and unforgiving environment and that led me to be weak.:Labour MP accused of calling a constituent an "ugly bitch"Mr OrsquoMara used his statement to blame Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn for how he had been treated by the party.At the time of his resignation from the Labour party, he revealed that he had made three suicide attempts at the height of the furore and described himself as ldquothe first autistic MP in our history.On Thursday, he said that discrimination he has suffered has led to the deterioration in his mental health to the point at which he recently ldquosuffered a delusional episode.He said: ldquoI want to become a better person again like I was.ldquoI feel Irsquove become unrecognisable and I want to make amends. I need treatment for my mental health and rest first though.A Labour Party spokesman said: ldquoWe take the welfare of our MPs very seriously and, while Jared is no longer a Labour MP, we are concerned for his welfare and we have continued to provide support to him, and will continue to do so.Olivia Blake, Labourrsquos candidate for the constituency, said:ldquoThis is the right decision for Jared and for the people of Sheffield Hallam, I hope he gets the support he needs.ldquoThe Labour Party is ready for a by-election. Hallam needs a Labour MP who will represent and support local people and seek to reverse the damage done by almost a decade of austerity under the Tories and the Lib Dems.Lib Dem prospective parliamentary candidate for the constituency Laura Gordon said:ldquoBy resigning Jared is doing the right thing ndash both for himself and his constituents.ldquoThis by-election can send a powerful message for change and the Lib Dems are ready for the challenge.Sir Nick held the seat in  despite a national backlash against the Lib Dems as traditional Tory voters were seen to shore up his support against Labour.The seat went Labour for the first time in  as the Tory vote swelled by more than % amid expectations of an easy Conservative win nationally.Mr OrsquoMara emerged the unexpected victor with a majority of , over the Lib Dems.

title: scottish-labour-leader-doctor-100-000-year-working-class
story: Leonard, who has endorsed calls to redefine class, said the label related to people are paid for their labour.A critic said this could mean company chief executives falling into this category, while Leonard has himself said a small business owner earning pound, a year would not.Since becoming leader in , Leonard has tried to sht the debate in Scotland from the constitution to issues relating to poverty, redistribution of wealth and public ownership.However, even his allies on the Left believe he has struggled to change the political weather, with the party slumping to fth place at the recent European election.Independence: is it the only way to save the Scottish Tories An important part of his political outlook is the belief in uniting people on the basis of their social class. In March last year he said: ldquoI am wedded to the John Maclean [a socialist during the Red Clydeside era] idea of rising with your class not out of your class. Trying to improve the outcome for everyone is something that appeals to me rather than asking how you can fulfil peoplersquos inidual aspirations."He also mentioned the word in his first conference speech as leader and claimed in December that ldquoworking class solidarity was the ldquoonly viable resistance to racism.Leonard mentioned ldquoclass on seven occasions in a recent piece and retweeted another article which focused on uniting working people across the country.In an interview with The Herald on Sunday in May, Leonard addressed his partyrsquos dismal result at the European election, but also he attempted to clary what he meant by class.Asked to define ldquoworking class in , he said: ldquoPeople who are paid for their labour.Put to him that this could include doctors, he replied: ldquoYes ... so long as they are not self-employed.ldquoYou can point to some people at the top end of that scale, but I think for the majority of people they may not see themselves socially as working class, but I would say that economically the vast majority of people in this country are working class.: New Scottish Secretary promised to help bankroll breakaway Tory partyAsked whether, according to this definition, a small business owner earning pound, a year would not qualy as working class, whereas a doctor on a six-figure salary who sells his labour would, he said:ldquoYes, because it is about your relationship with the economy. Itrsquos about where the balance of power lies in the economy, and whether you are an owner of wealth, or whether you are a creator of wealth.Leonard, who attended the Pocklington private school in Yorkshire on a scholarship, also addressed whether he considered himself to be working class: ldquoAs an elected politician, it is dficult to necessarily put me into a class. I am a servant of the people.However, asked the same question about his time working for the GMB trade union, the Old Pocklingtonian said: ldquoYes. And representing working class people to try and get justice.He added: ldquoThe construct of employment law in this country is still based on a master servant relationship.A Labour source said: ldquoBy Richardrsquos definition, someone employed as a chief executive would be considered working class. It seems flimsy.Paul Hutcheon: Ruth Davidsons chances of becoming FM depend on cutting Boris looseScottish Tory shadow finance secretary Murdo Fraser said: ldquoWhile Richard Leonard and his hard-left Labour cronies are tying themselves in knots over class, the rest of Scotland is just trying to get on with le.ldquoLabourrsquos obsession with class is rooted in bitterness and envy, and simply isnrsquot replicated anywhere across Scotland. Itrsquos no wonder their party is dying before their very eyes.

title: snp-government-agency-considers-closing-national-water-sports-centre
story: Sportscotland flagged up the closure of the decades-old facility at Cumbrae following a review and a decision is believed to be imminent. Staff have been told to turn down bookings.Scottish Tory MSP Brian Whittle said: ldquoThis facility is run by an SNP government agency ndash itrsquos their responsibility to make a success of this. Itrsquos simply not good enough to leave this axe dangling over the heads of staff.Sportscotlandrsquos role is to invest in the organisations and people who deliver sport and physical activity. It promotes an active Scotland and celebrates the benefits of sport north of the Border.A trust company owned by sportscotland also oversees three national centres ndash Glenmore Lodge, Inverclyde and Cumbrae ndash which offer opportunities to participate in ious sports.Cumbrae, an island whose sole town Millport has been a favoured retreat for generations of people from the west of Scotland, provides a range of activities including yachting, dinghy sailing, paddlesports, windsurfing and powerboating.However, a presentation to staff last month about a review of Cumbrae revealed that the centre is at risk.Scotlands Insider Guide: MillportThe update, obtained by this newspaper, highlighted its ldquohigh cost profile, as well as the ldquochanging needs of the sector.In the ldquoinitial options sections, the status quo was ldquoruled out by the Trust board. Reforms included redeveloping the existing site, relocation, closure, or the development of an alternative.The summary stated that the centre was set up to service the sector  years ago and that the island location is ldquoless desirable.It added that people want access to activities in ldquoclose proximity and claimed the cost profile is ldquounsustainable.In the ldquoclosure ndash what   section, sportscotland noted that staff would be informed following a formal decision.An email to staff after the meeting noted: ldquoI appreciate that the information was very dficult for staff to hear and is concerning for the future. I feel that you should be aware of the current status of the review regardless of the impact.It continued: ldquoWe are currently giving serious consideration to a new option of creating a Scottish National Sailing Academy in collaboration with RYA Scotland, Largs Yacht Haven, Largs Sailing Club and North Ayrshire Council.ldquoIf this were to be approved by the board then this would result in the closure of Cumbrae National Watersports Centre.It is understood a decision will be made by the trust board on August , with the outcome escalated to sportscotland later in the month.Regarding booking inquiries between November and February, staff were advised to turn them down by saying: ldquoDue to seasonal operational [changes] the centre will not be available during this time.The centre is popular with young people embarking on the Duke of Edinburgh Award and caters for school trips.Move over Tour de France: how Scotland could launch its own cycling tourFteen staff are employed at Cumbrae, in addition to  casual workers.West Scotland Green MSP Ross Greer said: ldquoClosure of the National Water Sports Centre would be a major blow to the community on Cumbrae. Irsquove raised the matter with the Scottish Government and hope that the Minister for Sport will intervene, recognising both the local and national importance of the centre.Whittle added: ldquoIf the nationalists are serious about improving health and activity, centres like this must play a pivotal role. Instead, it looks like the SNP is preparing to turn its back on it.A sportscotland spokesperson said: ldquoWe are currently undertaking a review of Cumbrae to determine the best provision of watersports in Scotland. We are looking at all options during the review and will make a decision by the end of the summer.

title: e-waiting-time-target-missed-280-000-times-last-two-years-say-lib-dems
story: The Scottish Governments AE target is for % of patients to either be admitted, transferred or discharged within four hours, but this goal has not been achieved since the week ending July , .Liberal Democrat health spokesman Alex Cole-Hamilton said it is "infuriating" the target has not been met since then.He said more investment in mental health services, primary care and social care could help cut the number of patients turning up at AE units.He was speaking after the Lib Dems calculated , patients had spent more than four hours in AE since the waiting times target was last achieved.This includes , patients who waited more than eight hours, and , who were there for  hours or longer.Mr Cole-Hamilton said: "It is infuriating for patients, and health professionals, that it is now two years since AE performance targets were met. In that time more than a quarter of a million people have waited too long in AE."A year ago we were welcoming a new Health Secretary to the role. Sadly, under Jeane Freeman we have seen no progress in tackling long waits."The average weekly performance against the AE target has actually worsened since her appointment."Doctors and nurses work incredibly hard, but they can only do so much. title: new-bed-boris-title-children-39-s-book
story: Eleanor had gone to the races dressed in a white jumpsuit. Unfortunately, only a couple of hours later, someone spilled red wine down her pristine outfit.Rather than cut her day short or rush home to change, Eleanor and her friends grabbed four glasses of red wine from the free bar. They went into the loos and tie-dyed her jumpsuit in the sink using the wine as dye to hide the stain.A few minutes under the hand drier and voila, she had an almost-new outfit. Think Jackson Pollock portraying a dusky pink sunset over a snow-capped valley. OK, I may be over-egging that slightly but, in truth, it didnt look half-bad.Most people can relate to Eleanors plight. It reminds me of the time a waiter accidentally dumped a plate of curry in my lap. Amid much profuse apologising, someone rustled up a spare pair of chefs whites and I was able to enjoy the rest of my meal looking like I had also cooked it.That is bested by a friend, though, who dined in an upmarket restaurant wearing tartan flannel pyjamas. It was her third outfit of the night. Shed started out in a posh frock, then ended up wearing a wine bucket.She recounts one of those comedy, slow-motion moments where the maitre d, who had been purposefully striding across the restaurant, unexpectedly found himself soaring through the air after tripping on an errant handbag strap snaking out from beneath a table.Attempting to regain his feet, the poor chap grabbed the nearest thing to hand. Cue the largely melted contents of an ice bucket being jettisoned towards my friend leaving her as drenched asshed gone over Niagara Falls in a barrel.:The secret regimes of celebrities and a toast to bevvy-themed namesHelp was at hand. Earlier that day, one of the waitresses had bought herself a pair of pyjamas from Primark. She offered them up to my grateful friend who was chittering with cold.My friend ed to drop off the freshly laundered pjs a couple of days later, along with a thank you note and gt. Talk about a dinner to remember.Goldilocks and his new bedYOU might have heard we have a new Prime Minister. As the latest incumbent of  Downing Street settles into his new pad, Boris Johnson is already facing criticism for reportedly spending thousands of pounds of taxpayers money on furniture, including a bed.A new bed for Boris  It sounds like the title of a childrens book. Which is somewhat appropriate as a man-child rocks up to run the country.You can picture the scene in the furniture shop with our political Goldilocks trying out all the beds until he finds one that is "just right" as in the fairy-tale with the three bears. There is a joke about Brexit, BoJo and making your bed in all of this, but Im simply too weary to deliver the punchline.Lets say the image that springs to mind is a lumpy futon that has been chucked out beside the bins and peed on by a passing dog.Relax hellip dont do itREGULAR readers of this column will know I have a penchant for dabbling in what could be loosely termed topical lestyle concepts. Or as my long-suffering husband prefers to call it: whatever-the-latest-nonsensical-fad-is-sigh.Already there has been a merry dance through Danish hygge , Scottish coorieand Finnish kalsarikannit .Now comes niksen, a Dutch relaxation technique which can be used as a method to combat work-related health problems, such as stress and burnout.The principle calls for the floating, rather than the focusing, of our thoughts. In short, permission to daydream. On paper, it sounds straightforward and blissful. Yet, as I have learned, doing nothing is not as easy as it looks. In fact, it is exhausting.Sample floating thoughts: "Beautul tree. Fluffy clouds. Oh, a plane! Where is that going  I wonder who is on board  That TV series Lost, the one where the plane crashed on a desert island, what was the ending about  Its been nine years and I still dont understand."Were they in purgatory that whole time  Was it a netherworld  Did they escape or die  Could I survive on a desert island  WhatI survived the plane crash but lost my glasses  Would I build a raft like Tom Hanks in Cast Away or wait for rescue :An ode to silly season and the unabashed joy it brings"What other films are set on a desert island  Robinson Crusoe. Swiss Family Robinson. Lord of the Flies. The Blue Lagoon. Oh, that makes me want chips. How long have I been doing this Niksen lark for now  That was a long two minutes hellip Enough, Im off to get pantsdrunk. And eat chips."

title: move-tour-de-france-scotland-launch-cycling-tour
story: After more than , miles of competition therersquos none today, bar the traditional finish on the Champs-Elysees which is left to the sprinters ndash the few who have survived the Pyrenean and Alpine torture ndash who still perhaps compete for their prize, the green jersey.But Le Tour isnrsquot just a magnicent and awe-inspiring athletic competition, itrsquos also an epic, spectacular and glorious prolonged advertisement for France, its culture, way of le and its countryside. Sponsors line up to support it and fund the teams ndash as Jim Ratclfersquos Ineos has done, taking over from Sky ndash while millions of tourists, and not just bike fans, crowd the routes, cling to the mountainsides, stay in hotels, drink in bars and cafes, and spend money on food and gts. Itrsquos a euro bonanza.Anyone who has seen the Tour live will have lasting memories, although the riders will have come and gone in seconds, starting in the hours before when the y sponsorsrsquo caravan comes through throwing out gts like T-shirts and sweets to the discarded ridersrsquo water bottles retrieved from the leading groups and the peloton, to the reminiscences afterwards, the photographs and the conversations in the town square bistros.But eventhe competitors at the heart of the event have bypassed quickly the large screens inside and outside will have been following on TV. From the cameras on the backs of motorbikes as they weave up and down the field to those in the helicopters overhead which donrsquot just capture the agony of the event below but the grandeur of the peaks and chateaux, to the eye-catching little tableaux put on by every village and town the route cuts through, from straw bales spelling out a message to massive art structures, down to sprayed support for a favourite rider on the roads.Ron McKay: Socks and dregs and rock n roll, beach le, the royal prerogative and the cautionary tale of a fat man slimmedSo why canrsquot we do it here  Why canrsquot we mount a race which will put Scotland at the forefront of the worldrsquos attention and which would pull in millions in sponsorship cash and tourist euros, dollars and yen and do more for the country in a year than VisitScotland. After all, Yorkshire piggy-backed on a Le Tour start and launched its own bike race ndash it is a real point of conversation for cycle fans and ordinary punters.And just think ndash even on a good day in Bronte Country, Yorkshire hasnrsquot a patch on bonny Scotland.As well as the sponsorship, the TV rights and spin-offs, French towns and cities compete for Le Tour to start and finish in their town or city, from around pound, to pound,, although this year Brussels is thought to have paid around pound million for the Grand Depart there.As with so many great ideas, the women have got there first, and this yearrsquos three-stage Womenrsquos Tour of Scotland sets off from Dundee on August .So surely, with so much wonderful scenery to celebrate and so much international exposure to be enjoyed, a full professional Tour along the lines of the French extravaganza is long overdue To encourage the Scottish Government to take this idea and run, or rather pedal, with it, wersquove devised our own -stage tour, showing off the best of the country.Wersquove also borne in mind that wersquove had to miss some worthy parts out because the infrastructure canrsquot now support the tour caravan, the dozens of cars and vans, the number of beds needed for riders and support, as well as the thousands of people who will drive there and line routes, supporting the riders.There would be intermediate sprints for prizes, also for hill and mountain wins, as well as prizes for the most combative rider of the day.As well as a yellow jersey for the winner there would also be inidual awards for the king of the mountains, a green jersey for the best sprinter, judged on points, and also an award for the young rider ndash under  ndash of the tour, judged on placing.Obviously, the roads involved would be closed for the duration of the lead-up to the stage and its aftermath. So here it goes, the Tour DrsquoEcosse is off ...Day OneThe Tour leaves from Glasgow and heads south to Girvan, across to New Cumnock, through Kilmarnock and back to Glasgow  kilometresDay TwoDepart from Glasgow, down through Clydebank and up along the side of Loch Lomond before the long climb to Crianlarich and the push to Glen Coe, Ballachulish and Fort William. Just over  kilometres.Day ThreeIn the shadow of Ben Nevis the tour heads to Spean Bridge and Invergarry, before a left-hander towards Morvich and Dornie before ending at Kyle of Lochalsh. A shorter stage, some km, but a punishing and rewarding one.Day FourItrsquos a tour of Skye. From Kyle across the bridge and through Broadford, Portree, up through Skeabost and round past Dunvegan, down through Sligachan and back to Kyle. kmDay FiveKyle to Inverness through Achnasheen and Dingwall. A stage of unexpected ndash and for many completely unknown ndash beauty. kmDay SixFrom Inverness down the Apast Aviemore and over the Pass of Drumochter, on to Dalwhinnie and Pitlochry, then across to Bridge of Cally and Blairgowrie, and on to Dundee. km.Day SevenTime trial from Dundee to Perth. km of predominantly flat going ndash one for the speed merchants.Day EightFrom Perth to Crieff, then Gleneagles, west to the Trossachs and finishing at Stirling. A stage of real iety and beauty. kmDay NineLeaving Stirling the riders head to Hamilton, the Biggar and up through Penicuik the Pentlands, to Musselburgh then Edinburgh, by way of Leith. kmDay TenThe last day. The survivors do a circuit of Edinburgh of km culminating in a sprint at the top of the Royal Mile or, for the yellow jersey, a perambulation round the sights of the capital.How does Le Tour work :: The winner is the rider who completes the course in the shortest time. So much so obvious. But hewonrsquot do it without the assistance of the seven other riders in the team and the technical back-up.:: Each team has a nominated leaderwith the other riders as domestiques, specialist sprinters or climbers , the workers who are at the service of the leader, chasing down breakaways or delaying the pack , leading pursuits, sheltering the boss from the winds, dropping back to help him hersquos in trouble, getting him drinks and feeding gels from the team cars.:: Each stage has intermediate sprints ndash and or climbs ndash which are sponsored with prizes and points for a half dozen or so riders. Itrsquos the same for the first few riders at the stage end, with the addition of a time bonus for the winner, usually six seconds over the rest.:: At the end of the tour the rider with the most sprint points wins the green jersey, the top climber wins the polka dot jersey, the overall winner the yellow ndash although in Tour DrsquoEcosse wersquoll go for a saltire on navy blue.:: It isnrsquot just an inidual race ndash teams are rated according to their combined times, with prizes. The teams are sponsored, in most cases by more than one company.:: The prize pot in Le Tour is relatively modest ndash when compared with Wimbledon or The Open ndash with a total of around pound million to be won, which the  teams and the  riders are competing for.:: The overall winner in the GC, the general classication, takes away pound, but, traditionally, splits the money with the seven other team members.

story: Ms Swinson, who was elected as leader of the Liberal Democrats earlier this week, said that although she would not stop campaigning for the UK to be a part of the European Union, she would then I would absolutely recognise that that was what the country had decided to do.ldquoAt the moment the dference is, and the dficulty is, that I donrsquot think there is a majority in this country story: The pound, project will help to restore  hectares of damaged and eroding peatland on the Isle of Lewis, taking in Loch Orasaigh - a strategically important drinking water supply in the Outer Hebrides.The restoration is being carried out by Scottish Natural Heritagersquos Peatland ACTION Project and Scottish Water and aims to re-profile peat hags, block drainage ditches and encourage the stabilisation of vegetation around the edge of the loch.Ben Inglis-Grant, SNHrsquos Peatland ACTION Project Officer, hosted by The Carloway Estate Trust, said: ldquoAround % of Scotlandrsquos peatlands are estimated to be damaged, through man-made drainage and other land-use pressures as well as natural erosion taking place.ldquoBy restoring our peatlands they can begin actively ing as they should, by storing water and capturing carbon.ldquoPeatland ACTION aims to make a dference across theand breadth of Scotland and by working together with Scottish Water, we can deliver multiple benefits to both people and nature, from carbon capture to clean drinking water and supporting natural ecosystems, which are so intrinsic to our existence.ldquoThese kind of nature-based solutions are also integral to tackling the climate emergency we are all facing.The project will also help preserve the local environment, with a recent survey confirming the loch is home to two of Scotlandrsquos protected species ndash Black Throated Divers and Great Skua.Commenting on the funding announcement, which coincided with International Bog Day on Sunday, Malcolm Walker, Scottish Water Catchment Liaison Officer, said: ldquoEvery day, Scottish Water provides . billion litres of clear fresh drinking water to its customers, much of which comes from peatland catchments. We are therefore acutely aware of the links between peatland condition and our drinking water catchments, having also worked with Peatland ACTION on other projects across Scotland.ldquoRestoring damaged peatlands by blocking man-made ditches and revegetating areas of bare peat may reduce the amount of peat being washed into our treatment works, which could lead to reduced treatment costs as well as helping protect and preserve the natural environment.SNH claims that preserving Scotlandrsquos peatlands means  years of the countryrsquos total annual greenhouse gas emissions are prevented from being released.

Aldrin Jr. Neil had ancestral links to Scotland. The name derives from Buzz Aldrin, the second man to walk on the Moon, and the Gaelic word for cow, Bò.Alex Keen, launch specialist from Sent into Space, said: “Launching at Gilnockie Tower was a real treat. Not only were the team from VisitScotland a great bunch to work with but the countryside we crossed in pursuit of our payload is one of the most beautul and dramatic landscapes we’ve visited. “Once the Coosmonaut was back in our hands, we were genuinely sad to leave and head back to England.”A new tourism map highlighting Scotland’s links to space exploration and the first moonwalk has also been released.On the new trail...among the Scottish landmarks on the new VisitScotland map is the dark sky observatory in Dalmellington, Ayrshire.The Scotland is Out of this World trail is part of the new Scotland is Out of this World campaign marks the th anniversary of the Apollo  mission and US astronaut Neil Armstrong’s historic walk on the lunar surface.But it also celebrates the th anniversary of our anniversary year we set our sights even further and travelled into space in what can only be described as a truly out of this world campaign.“Scotland is Out of this World offered the opportunity to delve into the past and celebrate the country’s contribution to space exploration and its ancestral links to one of the greatest moments in history.“The new trail reveals some of the country’s stellar attractions and locations to visit to firmly cement Scotland’s place in astro-tourism. “After all, our best views aren’t confined to our awe-inspiring landscapes but reach up high into the night sky above as well.”Ohio-born Neil Armstrong was proud of his Scottish heritage. The ancestral home of Clan Armstrong is Langholm in Dumfries and Galloway and in  he become the town’s first and only Freeman.Travel guide publisher, Lonely Planet, has identied dark skies as a tourism trend for .VisitScotland’s Insight team has created a research paper examining the opportunities for tourism businesses to engage with the trend.Scotland is home to two International Dark Sky Parks, Galloway Forest Park in Dumfries and Galloway and Tomintoul and Glenlivet in Cairngorms National Park. Isle of Coll is also a Dark Sky Island and Moffat a Dark Sky Town.To view the map, visit static.visitscotland pdf out-of-this-world-trail.pdf.First man on the moon’s Scottish linksNeil Armstrong, Buzz Aldrin and Michael Collins formed the three-man NASA mission which set off on July , , to land on the surface of the Moon. On the evening of July , Armstrong and Aldrin touched down on the lunar surface. Armstrong took “one giant leap for mankind” when he became the first person to walk on the moon.Three years after that historic moment, the Ohio-born NASA astronaut who commanded Apollo  took another “small step” into the history books in Langholm, the ancestral home of Clan Armstrong.There, in the “Muckle Toon”, he became the first and only person to be awarded the freedom of the burgh.Accepting the honour, he told the audience: “It’s said that the most dficult place to be recognised is in one’s own home town. And I consider this, now, my home town.” Many craters on the Moon and Mars are named after Scottish scientists. They include Aberdeen astronomers Arthur Mee and Sir David Gill and Edinburgh mathematician John Napier of Merchiston.The average distance from Earth to the Moon is about , miles .

title: garioch sports centre serves up an ace with new tennis plans
story: With the nation currently hooked on Wimbledon, it#s a fitting time for Garioch Sports Centre to unveil its new tennis-focused proposals.Inverurie Community Council has submitted fresh expansion plans to Aberdeenshire Council on behalf of Garioch Sports Holdings.Full planning permission was secured last year for a major extension of the Inverurie facility, but changes in the community’s requirements and pressures on funding have prompted a reduced development.Initially the plans would have seen the Burghmuir Drive centre expanding into one of the largest amenities of its kind in Scotland, incorporating tennis courts, a multi-sports arena, fitness suites and an all-weather G pitch for Inverurie Loco Works FC which has now been dropped.But while the scale of the expansion might not be as ambitious, the new plans do reveal tennis courts and improvements for fitness along with an Early Learning Centre for younger children.Thanks to signicant input from Judy Murray – mother of tennis stars Andy and Jamie – the plans feature three dedicated tennis courts and the centre has committed to a three-year partnership with the JM Foundation, highlighting the commitment of the centre to develop the sport across Garioch.The centre and JM Foundation will work in partnership in upskilling their workforce and identying potential coaches while funding coach education.In a supporting statement the centre writes: “The matter of securing the appropriate funding for the ious options which have been considered over the last couple of years has impacted upon how the plans have altered with the focus very much now being on the new tennis provision.“The most recent plans reflect the discussions with the Lawn Tennis Association and also Tennis Scotland.“The advice and guidance of Judy Murray has also been pivotal in how the plans particularly for the tennis courts have progressed.”The applicants also believe that despite the downturn in oil and gas and other industries, there is still a demand for its facilities.It reports: “As many of the activities and programmes now carry waiting lists, there is proof that despite a downturn in many industries the timing is now right to expand in tandem with the growth in participation and the increase in the town and rural residency.“An expansion of the present facility and delivery of its sporting, health and wellbeing activities has many positive additions as the market town itself strives to increase its provision to its residents.”data-src"https:images-o.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill title: inverurie scouts aiming to raise bags of cash for new air ambulance
story: Big-hearted Scouts are hoping to raise vital cash for a new air ambulance by collecting empty crisp packets.Inverurie Scout Group is supporting the ‘Crisps for Helimed ’ campaign to help raise cash for a second le-saving aircraft for the North-east by .By collecting crisp packets for recycling and fundraising, it will help bring a new £ million air ambulance to Aberdeen in .For every  bags recycled, £ will be donated to the charity.Scout group volunteer Jackie McBeath said: “This will be a great local asset for le-saving services in our area that we are proud to support.“We are also very aware of the environmental issues affecting us globally and are delighted to be able to do a little to help the world we live in.”The idea came from Inverurie Scout Group Explorer leader Ross Couttie who had heard of the Helimed initiative and thought it was a good idea for the group which boasts more than  members from Beavers, Cubs, Scouts and Explorers.Jackie explained: “He got in touch with Crisps for Helimed  and ordered a box for collecting them. We have already asked all our members to start collecting empty crisp packets and are setting up a collection point in our Scout Hut.“We will be collecting all crisp packets including large bags and the multi pack bags as well as popcorn and other snacks bags.“We think that now is an ideal time for our members to start collecting as over the summer holidays people have more picnics and snacks especially in this gorgeous weather. “Inverurie Scout Group can’t wait to see how many we get when our section meetings start up again in August..The group has appealed to the local community to join in and drop-off off collections at the Scout Hut at section meetings duringterm-time. Those interested in helping can also contact the group via its Facebook page at InverurieScoutGroup and the team will arrange to collect them locally.data-src"https:images-o.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"Sophie Miah has been traced safe and well"  Missing Kemnay girl Sophie traced safe and well viewBox"  . ." enable-background"new   . ." xml:space"preserve"c,,.-,.-.c-,-.,.-.C.,.,,,,.z"  Coremetrics  Coremetrics  Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventID  "INVE | Article Teaser"Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventCatID  "INVE | Article Teaser"

title: age scotland make hot weather plea
story: Age Scotland is urging people to check on older neighbours, family and friends who may be more at risk of health problems in increased temperatures, this summer.The Met Office has predicted that, today, Thursday could be the hottest day on record in the UK.While many people are enjoying the balmy weather, the charity is warning that older people and those with health conditions should be especially careful.According to Age Scotland, hot weather can exacerbate existing health issues — such as heart and lung conditions  — while people with reduced mobility might find it more challenging to keep cool. People living with dementia might not remember to drink enough liquids to stay hydrated or wear appropriate clothing for the weather.Prolonged exposure to excessive heat can lead to heat exhaustion, with symptoms including headaches, dizziness, nausea or vomiting, intense thirst, heavy sweating and a fast pulse. It can be le-threateninguntreated.Michelle Supple, director of charity services at Age Scotland said: “While many of us are having fun in the sun, it’s important to remember that warm weather can present health risks, especially for older people.“People with heart or lung conditions, those with reduced mobility or living with dementia can be especially vulnerable when temperatures go up. As we age, it becomes more dficult to regulate our body temperature and this can be exacerbated by some medications.“It’s important to take simple steps to stay cool, including drinking plenty of fluids, limiting strenuous activities, and staying inside during the warmest part of the day. It’s also vital to protect your skin by using sunscreen and covering up with a wide-brimmed hat and loose-fitting clothes.“We would encourage everyone to check on older neighbours, friends and family to make sure they are doing well and seethey need anything. title: join in in scotlands biggest beach clean
story: newsJoin in in Scotland#s biggest beach cleanJuly ,  at : pm vw, px"  The UK’s leading marine charity, the Marine Conservation Society , is looking for volunteers to clean up Scotland’s beaches this September  to  during its  Great British Beach Clean event.Although there are currently no beach cleans scheduled in Orkney, the charity are encouraging folks to get in touch and organise there own.Last year, , volunteers took part, removing an incredible , inidual items of litter, weighing ,kg, at  beach cleans along , metres of surveyed coastline.The Great British Beach Clean is not just a beach cleaning event, however. Volunteer cleaners become citizen scientists, as they also record the litter they find along a designated m stretch of every beach that’s cleaned, and it’s this aspect that has helped MCS change policy and behaviours over the last  years.“Now more than ever is the time to turn awareness into action,# says Catherine Gemmell, MCS Scotland conservation officer. #Everybody is talking about marine litter — you see it on the TV, hear it on the radio and read it in the papers and across social media. We want people to take that awareness and turn it into action by taking part in the biggest beach litter survey and clean up in Scotland! Only by combining awareness with action and data can we make sure that industry and government put in place the urgent measures needed to stop this plastic tide for good.”The p carrier bag charge, a ban on microbeads in wash-off products, consultations on a plastic tax, commitments to depositschemes, a ban on plastic stemmed cotton buds in Scotland and the banning of lantern and balloon releases — have all come about following compelling evidence gathered over decades by volunteers at MCS beach cleans. Cleaning and surveying a beach only takes a couple of hours at most. Each beach has a coordinator, who explains how to fill in a simple data form, and then it’s just a case of grabbing a litter picker and a bin bag and filling it up with rubbish.“Beach litter is a serious environmental problem,” says Lizzie Prior, MCS Beachwatch Officer.“But the solution is in our hands. We want the th Great British Beach Clean weekend to be the biggest ever. The BBC’s Blue Planet II and subsequent programmes have given the UK public a real understanding of the pollution crisis facing our oceans and now people want to make a dference. The more volunteers we have, the better it’ll be for our seas.”To get involved, call   and find out how you can organise your own.copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co.
